questions.text: A 15-year-old boy, a known case of type I DM, undergoes the following test for the detection of KB. Which is this test: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rothera's Test

 

The test used for the detection of ketone bodies (KB) in the given scenario of a 15-year-old boy with type I diabetes mellitus is Rothera's Test.

 

Rothera's Test involves the reaction of acetoacetate with sodium nitroprusside and glycine in an alkaline medium. This reaction forms a purple-colored complex, indicating the presence of ketone bodies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Benedict's test is used to detect the presence of reducing sugars, such as glucose, in a solution.

 

Option C. Seliwanoff's test is used to differentiate between different types of sugars, particularly distinguishing ketoses from aldoses.

 

Option D. Biuret test The Biuret test is used to detect the presence of proteins in a sample by reacting with peptide bonds.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rothera's Test is a commonly used laboratory test to detect the presence of ketone bodies, specifically acetoacetate, in urine or blood samples. It is particularly relevant in the context of diabetes mellitus, as individuals with uncontrolled diabetes, especially type I diabetes, may experience an increase in ketone production.

 

In type I diabetes, the body is unable to produce sufficient insulin, resulting in a lack of glucose utilization by cells for energy. As a result, the body begins to break down fats as an alternative energy source, leading to the production of ketone bodies, including acetoacetate.

choices.text: Light blue → Red → Lavender → Grey
Light blue → Lavender → Red → Grey
Grey → Red → Light blue → Lavender
Red → Lavender → Grey → Light blue

questions.text: The phlebotomist needs to collect samples from a patient for various tests. Among the options provided, which sequence of blood collection for testing ensures that the sample remains uncontaminated, considering the additives present in the collection tubes? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Light blue → Red → Lavender → Grey

 

The Clinical & Laboratory Standards Institute (CLSI) has provided a recommended color sequence for collecting multiple venous and/or arterial blood samples from a single patient: Yellow, Pink, Light Blue, Red, Green, Lavender, And Grey.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The accurate color sequence for the blood collection tubes is as follows:

 

Light blue → Red → Lavender → Grey

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl arrives with several swellings and numerous brown rashes. Bone scans reveal heightened activity in the femur, skull, and rib areas. There are irregularities in her biochemical values. Additionally, she has a past medical record of hypothyroidism. The provided image displays an X-ray of her femur. What is the probable diagnosis from the options provided?(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. McCune-Albright syndrome

 

MCCUNE ALBRIGHT SYNDROME

 

  • Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia (multiple bones involved)
  • Precocious puberty (endocrine abnormalities)
  • Cutaneous Pigmentation (café Au lait: coffee-colored spots)
  • The cafe au lait spots have characteristically irregular ragged borders (commonly called “coast of Maine” bor- ders), as opposed to the smoothly marginated borders (“coast of California”) of the spots seen in neurofibromatosis.
  • Surgical treatment by curettage + bone grafting is indicated when significant deformity or pathological fracture occurs or when significant pain exists.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Langerhans cell histiocytosis. It is the idiopathic destruction of histiocytes. The disease has characteristics of both an abnormal reactive process and a neoplastic process. It may present initially as a rash, and can disseminate and involve bone marrow, lungs, liver, spleen, lymph nodes, gastrointestinal (GI) tract, and the pituitary gland. Histologically, the primary lesion is granulomatous with an influx of eosinophils, macrophages, T cells and multinucleated cells. The Birbeck granule is the microscopic hallmark of the disorder but may not be seen in lesions of the spleen, liver, and GI tract. The rash may be distinguished by the presence of petechiae, bloody crusting, or firmly indurated nodules. Bony involvement occurs in 78% patients. Solitary osseous lesions are incidentally found and may include the skull, hip/pelvis, femur, or ribs. This bony involvement may produce bone pain. In long bones, endosteal scalloping may be responsible for a “budding appearance”.

 

 

Endosteal scalloping presenting as budding appearance

 

Option C. Neuroma with bone involvement. Morton's neuroma is one of the most common pain syndromes affecting the forefoot. It is characterized by tenderness and burning pain in the plantar surface of the forefoot, with painful paresthesias in the two affected toes. This pain syndrome is caused by perineural fibrosis of the interdigital nerves. Although the nerves between the third and fourth toes are affected most commonly, the second and third toes and, rarely, the fourth and fifth toes can be affected as well. Patients may feel like they are walking with a stone in the shoe. The pain worsens with prolonged standing or walking for long distances and is exacerbated by poorly fitting or improperly padded shoes. Morton's neuroma is associated with wearing tight, narrow-toed shoes. On physical examination, pain can be reproduced by firmly squeezing the 2 metatarsal heads together with one hand while placing firm pressure on the interdigital space with the other hand. This maneuver is known as the Mulder sign. The patient exhibits an antalgic gait in an effort to reduce weight bearing during walking.

 

 

Option D. Papillary carcinoma of thyroid. Papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) is an epithelial malignancy showing follicular cell differentiation and nuclear features. It is the most frequent thyroid neoplasm. The tumor usually appears as an irregular solid mass. One key feature is the ability to invade adjacent structures like lymphatics. About 10% patients may present with metastatic disease at initial presentation. It usually presents as an asymptomatic thyroid mass with or without enlargement of regional (cervical) lymph nodes. Hoarseness and dysphagia occur in approximately 20% cases, signaling recurrent laryngeal nerve involvement with vocal cord paralysis or tracheal compression. Nodal metastases in the lateral neck are reported in 27% patients. The examination reveals a painless hard lesion of less than 5 cm. The mass is often fixed and has irregular borders.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The presentation of several swellings and numerous brown rashes represents café Au lait spots.
  • Bone scans reveal heightened activity in the femur, skull, and rib areas.
  • There are irregularities in her biochemical values.
  • Presence of past medical history of hypothyroidism, and Shepherd crook deformity of femur in the given image, all point towards the McCune Albright Syndrome.

questions.text: Below is an electron microscopy depiction of a cellular structure. Determine the type of cell being depicted: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hairy cell

 

Hairy cells are seen in Hairy cell leukemia. It is a B-cell tumor. Peripheral smear shows pancytopenia; hairy cells. Flow cytometry shows CD11/25/103 + cells. Annexin –A is the best marker.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Target cell: Target cell can be seen in thalassemia, hepatic disease with jaundice, hemoglobin C disorders, and the postsplenectomy state.

 

 

Option C. Gaucher cell: Gaucher cell is found in Gaucher’s disease which occurs due to absence of beta glucocerebrosidase enzyme..

 

 

Option D. Sickle cells: Sickle cells are seen in sickle cell anemia. HbS has altered solubility and high chance of polymer formation especially with dehydration or hypoxemia causing alteration in shape. On rehydration, it is reversible.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hairy cells, with their distinctive cytoplasmic projections, are a hallmark of Hairy Cell Leukemia, a chronic B-cell malignancy.

questions.text: Which of the following is an anti-apoptotic factor? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) MCL 1

 

MCL 1 is an anti-apoptotic gene which prevents apoptosis by binding to and neutralizing pro-apoptotic proteins such as BAX and BAK. MCL1 plays a crucial role in resistance to chemotherapy drugs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PUMA: PUMA (p53 upregulated modulator of apoptosis) is a pro-apoptotic gene that is activated by p53 and plays a role in promoting apoptosis by inhibiting anti-apoptotic BCL-2 family members.

 

Option B. BAD: BAD is another pro-apoptotic protein that promotes apoptosis by binding to and inhibiting anti-apoptotic proteins such as BCL-2 and BCL-XL.

 

Option C. BAK: BAK is a pro-apoptotic protein that, when activated, oligomerizes and disrupts the mitochondrial membrane, leading to cytochrome c release and the activation of caspases, which are crucial for apoptosis.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
What are the components of Nada's Minor Criteria? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Systolic mumur Grade 3
  2. Diastolic murmur
  3. Abnormal second heart sound
  4. Abnormal BP
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 3 and 4

 

Nada’s criteria is used for detection of CHD on the basis of clinical evaluation.

 

 

Presence of 1 major or 2 minor criteria suggest presence of heart disease.

 

Educational Objective:
 

In Nada’s criteria for detecting congenital heart disease, minor criteria include an abnormal second heart sound and abnormal blood pressure. The presence of one major or two minor criteria suggests the presence of heart disease.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is the causative agent associated with in this case? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pure red cell aplasia

 

  • The provided picture displays the typical appearance of a slapped cheek  due to cutaneous vasodilatation, indicating a probable case of erythema infectiosum.
  • This condition is caused by the Parvovirus B19.
  • Parvovirus B19 is linked to pure red cell aplasia.

 

MANIFESTATIONS OF PARVOVIRUS B19

 

1. Fetus

  • Severe anemia (transient aplastic crises)
  • Pure red cell aplasia
  • Congestive heart failure
  • Hydrops fetalis
  • Spontaneous abortion

 

 

2. Children/adults

  • Fifth disease, erythema infectiosum, slapped cheek fever
  • 7−10-day incubation
  • Nonspecific “flu-like” symptoms followed by raised, indurated facial rash (Slapped cheek)

 

 

3. Adults

  • Rash and arthralgias (involves wrist most often) are due to immune complexes in the skin and joints.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gingivostomatitisis can be caused by Herpes virus.

 

Option C. Molluscum contagiosum is an infection caused by a poxvirus 

 

Option D. Kaposi sarcoma is caused by human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parvovirus B19, the causative agent of erythema infectiosum, is associated with pure red cell aplasia, particularly in individuals with underlying hemolytic disorders.

questions.text:
Among the given statements, which one would lead you to consider primary amenorrhea as a possibility? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Failure to attain menarche by 15 years of age
  2. Failure to attain menarche even after 3 years of thelarche
  3. High levels of TSH and short stature
  4. Failure of development of breasts by 13 years of age
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 4

 

Primary amenorrhea is defined as the absence of menstruation in a girl who has not attained menarche by a certain age or who lacks secondary sexual characteristics. Specifically:

 

1. Failure to attain menarche by 15 years of age: This is a classic indicator of primary amenorrhea, particularly if secondary sexual characteristics have developed. It is an age by which menstruation should have started if there are signs of puberty.

 

2. Failure to attain menarche even after 3 years of thelarche: Thelarche, or breast development, typically occurs around ages 9 to 13. If menarche has not occurred within 3 years after thelarche, it is a reason to investigate primary amenorrhea.

 

4. Failure of development of breasts by 13 years of age: The absence of breast development by age 13 indicates a delay in puberty and warrants evaluation for primary amenorrhea if menstruation has not begun by this age.

 

Other Option:

 

3. High levels of TSH and short stature: While high TSH and short stature may indicate thyroid dysfunction or other endocrine issues, they are not direct indicators of primary amenorrhea. These findings might contribute to secondary causes of amenorrhea or other growth disorders but are not themselves diagnostic criteria for primary amenorrhea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary amenorrhea should be considered if there is failure to attain menarche by 15 years of age, failure to attain menarche even after 3 years of thelarche, or failure of breast development by 13 years of age.

questions.text: All of the options listed can be utilized for assessing data normalcy except? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mantel-Haenszel test

 

  • The Mantel Haenszel test is used for sample sets that are able to be placed in two by two tables, but unlike the Fisher Exact test and the chi-squared test, there is no “n” requirement.
  • Normality of a data refers to a specific statistical distribution called a normal distribution, or sometimes the Gaussian distribution or bell-shaped curve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Plot histogram: Correct for assessing data normalcy. A histogram can visually show whether data follow a normal distribution.

 

Option C. Box whisker: Correct for assessing data normalcy. A box-and-whisker plot (box plot) can reveal the symmetry and spread of data, indicating normality.

 

Option D. Shapiro Wilk test: Correct for assessing data normalcy. The Shapiro-Wilk test is a statistical test specifically designed to test the normality of data.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Mantel-Haenszel test is not used for assessing the normality of data. Normality can be assessed using tools like plot histograms, box-and-whisker plots, Shapiro-Wilk test, Kolmogorov–Smirnov test, etc.

questions.text: What does the provided formula correspond to? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Standard deviation

 

  • Standard deviation is the Root of Mean od Squares of Deviations

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Variance: Variance = (Standard deviation)2

 

Option C. Mean: Mean is obtained as sum of all values divided by the number of values in the distribution. It is not affected by extreme values.

 

Option D. Median: Median is the middle most value in a distribution arranged in an ascending or descending order of values.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The standard deviation measures the dispersion of a data set around its mean.

choices.text: At eight weeks the embryo is bipotent
Wolffian duct develops into epididymis and vas deferens on either side of the body
Mullerian inhibiting substance inhibits mullerian duct
Dihydrotestosterone leads to the development of secondary sexual characters and external genitalia

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about male sexual development? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) At eight weeks the embryo is bipotent

 

Explanation:

 

At eight weeks of gestation, the embryo is no longer bipotent. The term "bipotent" refers to the embryo's capability to develop into either male or female structures, which is true up until about the sixth week of development. By the eighth week, sexual differentiation is already underway, with the influence of the SRY gene causing the gonads to differentiate into testes in 46XY embryos. This differentiation results in a shift away from bipotency, making the embryo committed to developing male characteristics.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Wolffian duct develops into epididymis and vas deferens on either side of the body: This statement is true. The Wolffian ducts, under the influence of testosterone, develop into the male reproductive structures including the epididymis and vas deferens.

 

Option C. Mullerian inhibiting substance inhibits Mullerian duct: This statement is true. Mullerian inhibiting substance (MIS), also known as anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH), is produced by Sertoli cells in the testes and inhibits the development of the Mullerian ducts, which would otherwise develop into female reproductive structures such as the uterine tubes and uterus.

 

Option D. Dihydrotestosterone leads to the development of secondary sexual characters and external genitalia: This statement is true. Dihydrotestosterone (DHT), a potent metabolite of testosterone, is crucial for the development of male external genitalia and secondary sexual characteristics such as facial hair and a deeper voice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

At eight weeks of gestation, the embryo is no longer bipotent; sexual differentiation has already commenced.

questions.text: In the case of an elderly male presenting with meningitis, a gram stain of the CSF sample shows the presence of gram-positive bacilli. Which of the following statements accurately pertains to the motility of the responsible microorganism? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Motile at 25° C, non-motile at 37°C

 

  • The provided case involves an elderly man with meningitis, and the smear analysis indicates the presence of a gram-positive bacillus, strongly indicative of a Listeria infection. Listeria exhibits motility at 25°C but loses its ability to move at 37°C.

 

LAB DIAGNOSIS OF LISTERIA MONOCYTOGENES

 

  • Motility: shows differential motility, which is due to temperature dependent flagella expression) 
    • Tumbling type of motility at 25°C
    • Non-Motile at 37°C
  • Culture → Blood agar, Chocolate agar
  • Selective media → PALCAM agar

 

TREATMENT

 

  • Meningitis → DOC → Ampicillin in combination with gentamicin for synergistic effect
  • Penicillin allergy → Cotrimoxazole
  • In febrile gastroenteritis → Amoxicillin

 

Educational Objective:

 

Listeria monocytogenes exhibits motility at 25°C but is non-motile at 37°C.

choices.text: Pain begins after few hours of onset of periods and can last up to 48 hours
It is dependent on psychological factors
Pain begins 3 days prior to the onset of periods and is present up to the second day of the period
GnRH antagonists are the first line of treatment

questions.text: Which of these statements regarding primary dysmenorrhea is true? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It Is dependent on psychological factors

 

Primary dysmenorrhea can be dependent on psychological factors.

 

Secondary dysmenorrhea is associated with the presence of pelvic pathologies.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Pain begins after few hours of onset of periods and can last up to 48 hours and Option C. Pain begins 3 days prior to the onset of periods and is present up to the second day of the period: Pain begins before or with onset of menstrual periods.

 

Option D. GnRH antagonists are the first line of treatment: NSAIDs are the first line of treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary dysmenorrhea, characterized by menstrual pain without underlying pelvic pathology, can be influenced by psychological factors. This type of dysmenorrhea begins before or with the onset of menstrual periods and is typically treated first with NSAIDs, not GnRH antagonists.

questions.text: In a 46XY female complete gonadal dysgenesis was noted. Complete gonadal dysgenesis is caused by what in the SRY gene?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Point mutation

 

Swyer syndrome (46,XY complete gonadal dysgenesis) most often results from a point mutation in the SRY gene, which disrupts testis determination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Extra copy of the gene: Not seen in this condition.

 

Option C. Entire Y chromosome missing: Would make the karyotype 45,X (Turner syndrome), not Swyer syndrome.

 

Option D. Gene turned upside down (inversion): Not the usual cause of gonadal dysgenesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Complete gonadal dysgenesis in a 46XY female is most commonly associated with a point mutation in the SRY gene. This results in underdeveloped gonads, failure of androgen and AMH production, and a female phenotype with normal mullerian structures.

questions.text: A patient with chronic kidney disease has the following laboratory reports. Calculate the anion gap in this patient. Na+: 145 mEq/L, K+ 4 mEq/L Cl: 90 mEq/L HCO3: 20 mEq/L. (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 35


The anion gap is calculated using the formula:

 

Anion Gap = Na−(Cl+HCO3)
 

Anion Gap=145−(90+20)=35

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anion gap is calculated as Na - (Cl + HCO3), and a high anion gap may indicate metabolic acidosis.

choices.text: Collagen is a type of fibrous protein, which is most abundant of all human proteins
Post translational hydroxylation of proline & lysine
Triple helix is required for its function

questions.text: Which of the following is false about collagen: (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Most abundant AA is Phenyl-alanine

 

Collagen is a fibrous protein that is indeed the most abundant protein in the human body. It provides structural support to various tissues, including skin, bones, tendons, and blood vessels. However, the most abundant amino acid in collagen is actually glycine, not phenylalanine. Glycine makes up approximately one-third of the amino acids in the collagen protein chain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Collagen is a type of fibrous protein that is the most abundant protein in the human body. It forms a strong and flexible structure in various tissues.

 

Option C. Post-translational hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues is an essential process in collagen synthesis. This hydroxylation is necessary for the proper formation and stability of collagen's triple helix structure.

 

Option D. The triple helix structure is a characteristic feature of collagen and is crucial for its function. Collagen molecules are composed of three polypeptide chains, coiled around each other in a triple helical arrangement. This structure provides collagen with its strength and stability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognizing the correct composition of collagen is essential to understand its structural role in the human body.

choices.text: Documentation of injuries and examination findings

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl, accompanied by her mother, is brought to a lady police sub-inspector, alleging a history of sexual violence that occurred two days ago. The next course of action for the registered medical practitioner would be?(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Take a detailed history

 

The next course of action involves the registered medical practitioner gathering a comprehensive medical history.

 

The registered medical professional must conduct a comprehensive medical history review and obtain informed consent before proceeding with the examination. If the individual declines the examination, a well-documented informed refusal must be obtained, clearly explaining the potential consequences of their decision.

 

During the examination process, the medical practitioner should gather necessary specimens, preserve any relevant clothing, and meticulously document all injuries and findings. It is essential to provide free medical treatment and conduct pregnancy testing for all victims of sexual assault, as mandated by law under section 357-C of CrPc. Additionally, the police must be notified accordingly.

 

Other Options

 

Option B: Preserve clothing: Preserving clothing is essential for forensic evidence but should follow after taking a detailed history to ensure the context is understood and evidence is collected appropriately.

 

Option C: Take consent for genital examination: Taking consent for a genital examination is critical but must come after obtaining a detailed history to ensure the examination is conducted respectfully and with full understanding of the context.

 

Option D: Documentation of injuries and examination findings: Documentation of injuries and examination findings is vital for forensic and medical records but should be done after taking a detailed history and obtaining informed consent.

 

Educational Objective

 

In cases of alleged sexual violence, the initial and crucial step for the registered medical practitioner is to take a detailed history from the victim.

questions.text: During her pregnancy, the lady regularly cleans her cat's litter to prevent toxoplasma infection. What is the specific infective stage of this organism found in the cat feces? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Oocysts

 

Oocysts are the infective stage of Toxoplasma gondii that are shed in the feces of infected cats. These oocysts are highly resistant and can survive in the environment for extended periods, becoming infectious to other hosts, including humans, once they sporulate. When a pregnant woman comes into contact with these oocysts, there is a risk of transmitting the infection to the fetus, which can lead to serious congenital abnormalities.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bradyzoites are the form of Toxoplasma that are found within tissue cysts in intermediate hosts.

 

Option B. Tissue cysts, containing bradyzoites, are found in intermediate hosts such as rodents and birds, and not in cat feces.

 

Option C. Tachyzoites are the rapidly multiplying form of the parasite that disseminates throughout the host's tissues during acute infection but are not the form found in cat feces.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The specific infective stage of Toxoplasma gondii found in cat feces is the oocyst, which poses a risk of infection if ingested.

Match the following positions of the appendix: (INICET MAY 2023)

 

 

  1. Subcaecal
  2. Retrocaecal
  3. Inside the pelvis
  4. Paracaecal
questions.solution: Ans. C) 1-b, 2-d, 3-a, 4-c

questions.text: Which of the following procedures is not performed via the perineal approach in a patient with rectal prolapse? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ripstein operation

 

This procedure is designed to treat rectal prolapse. It involves fixing the rectum to the sacrum using a synthetic mesh. This procedure is performed via an abdominal approach and not through the perineum. Hence, the answer to the question is A) Ripstein operation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thiersch operation: The Thiersch operation is a perineal procedure. It involves placing a wire or other synthetic material around the anus to encircle and narrow it. This provides support to the anal canal and rectum, helping to prevent or treat rectal prolapse.

 

Option C. Altemeier procedure: Also known as the perineal rectal resection, the Altemeier procedure is a surgical treatment for rectal prolapse. During this operation, the prolapsed portion of the rectum is resected, and the remaining rectum is sutured back to the anal canal. This procedure is performed through the perineal approach.

 

Option D. Delorme operation: The Delorme operation is a perineal approach to treat rectal prolapse. The mucosa and submucosa of the prolapsed rectum are excised, and the muscularis is plicated. The remaining mucosa is then sutured back. This procedure is typically reserved for older patients or those who are not candidates for a more invasive abdominal procedure.

choices.text: Routine Ha & E

questions.text: Identify the histopathological image: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Amyloidosis

 

The given image demonstrates Congo red stain showing Pink red appearance under normal light. This stain is used in diagnosis of Amyloidosis.

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Elastic fibers: Elastic fibers can be demonstrated by Verhoeff-van Gieson Stain.

 

 

Option B. Routine H & E: Routine H & E is done by Hematoxylin and eosin stain. The hematoxylin stains cell nuclei a purplish blue, and eosin stains the extracellular matrix and cytoplasm pink.

 

 

Option D. Collagen: Collagen can be demonstrated by Masson trichrome stain. It gives blue color to the collagen, black color to nuclei and red to muscle present.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congo red staining, showing pink-red deposits under normal light, is characteristic of amyloid and is a key diagnostic tool for amyloidosis.

questions.text: La belle indifference is seen in which of the following conditions? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Conversion disorder

 

La Belle indifference can be seen in Conversion disorder.

 

CONVERSION DISORDER

 

ICD-11 uses the term ‘dissociative neurological symptom disorder’

 

  • Patients present with symptoms suggestive of motor, sensory or cognitive deficits; however, no neurological cause can be found.
  • Also, the symptoms do not conform to the anatomical and physiological principles

 

Patients may have ‘la belle indifference’, which is a lack of concern for the symptoms. E.g., A patient with sudden onset loss of vision in an eye may appear unconcerned with her symptom.

questions.text:
Which of these options are considered direct gonioscopes?(INICET May 2023)

 

  1. Goldmann
  2. Richardson
  3. Zeis
  4. Koeppe
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2, 4

 

Richardson and Koeppe are direct gonioscopes.

 

DIRECT GONIOSCOPY - It is performed with a steep convex lens which permits light from the angle to exit the eye closer to the perpendicular at the lens - air interface. These lenses are used with an operating microscope.

 

DIRECT GONIOSCOPE IMAGE

 

 

Examples –

 

  • Koeppe goniolens
  • Richardson- Shaffer's lens
  • Sieback goniolens
  • Worth goniolens
  • Swan Jacob's lens
  • Huskins barkan's lens

 

INDIRECT GONIOSCOPY - uses mirrors or prism to overcome the problem of total internal reflection. Moreover, it uses the slit lamp's illumination and magnification system to its advantage.

 

INDIRECT GONIOSCOPE IMAGE

 

 

Examples –

 

  • Goldmann Gonioprism
  • Zeis Gonioprism
  • Tokel Gonioprism

 

Educational Objective:

 

Direct gonioscopes like Richardson and Koeppe provide a detailed and direct view of the anterior chamber angle, which is valuable in diagnostic and certain therapeutic procedures.

questions.text:
Which muscles receive innervation from the Superior Gluteal Nerve? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

1. Gluteus Medius

2. Gluteus Minimus

3. Tensor fascia lata

4. Piriformis
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1, 2, 3

 

Superior Gluteal Nerve (L4, L5, S1) supplies to Gluteus Medius, Minimus and Tensor Fascia Lata (damage leads to positive Trendelenburg sign). Accompanied by the superior gluteal vessels, the nerve leaves the pelvis via the greater sciatic foramen above piriformis, and divides into superior and inferior branches. The superior branch accompanies the upper branch of the deep division of the superior gluteal artery to supply gluteus medius and occasionally gluteus minimus. The inferior branch runs with the lower ramus of the deep division of the superior gluteal artery across gluteus minimus, supplies the glutei medius and minimus and ends in tensor fasciae latae.

 

Piriformis is supplied by the nerve to the piriformis (S1, S2).

 

 

1. Gluteus Medius: True. The gluteus medius muscle receives innervation from the superior gluteal nerve. This nerve supplies motor neurons to the gluteus medius and plays a crucial role in the abduction and stabilization of the hip joint.
 

2. Gluteus Minimus: True. Similar to the gluteus medius, the gluteus minimus muscle is also innervated by the superior gluteal nerve. It functions in hip abduction and stabilization.
 

3. Tensor Fascia Lata (TFL): True. The tensor fascia lata muscle, often referred to as the TFL, receives innervation from the superior gluteal nerve. This muscle assists in various movements, including flexion, abduction, and medial rotation of the hip.

 

Other Option

 

4. Piriformis: False. The piriformis muscle is not innervated by the superior gluteal nerve. Instead, it is primarily innervated by the nerve to the piriformis, which arises from the sacral plexus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gluteus Medius, Gluteus Minimus, and Tensor Fascia Lata receive innervation from the Superior Gluteal Nerve (L4, L5, and S1 nerve roots). Piriformis, on the other hand, is innervated by one of the branch of sacral plexus.

questions.text: The vector shown in the image below transmits which of the following organism? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Orientia tsutsugamushi

 

  • The picture depicts a trombiculid mite, known for transmitting Orientia tsutsugamushi.

 

SCRUB TYPHUS (ORIENTIA)

 

  • Caused by → Orientia tsutsugamushi
  • Vector → Trombiculid mites (Leptotrombidium)
  • Chiggerosis → Among all stages of mite, larvae (called chiggers) are only stage that feed on humans. Hence, scrub typhus is also called chiggerosis.
  • Clinical manifestations
    • Eschar (at the site of bite)
    • Regional lymphadenopathy
    • Maculopapular rash
  • DOC → Doxycycline

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Kyasanur forest disease: Kyasanur forest disease is vector borne disease caused by hard tick.

 

 

Option C. Chandipura virus: Chandipura virus is vector borne disease transmitted by sandfly

 

 

Option D. Anaplasma: Anaplasma is a tick-borne disease affecting ruminants, dogs, and horses, and is caused by Anaplasma bacteria. Mainly transmitted by Ixodes ticks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The trombiculid mite, particularly in its larval stage called a chigger, transmits Orientia tsutsugamushi, the causative agent of scrub typhus.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female is diagnosed with breast cancer. Her tumor is found to be HER2-positive but estrogen receptor (ER) and progesterone receptor (PR) negative. The tumor was resistant to trastuzumab. Which of the following drugs is most likely to be effective in the treatment of this patient's breast cancer?(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Lapatinib

 

Lapatinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor that can be used for the treatment of HER2-positive but trastuzumab-resistant breast cancer. Trastuzumab is a monoclonal antibody that is commonly used for the treatment of HER2-positive breast cancer, but some patients may develop resistance to this drug over time. Lapatinib works by targeting the HER2 receptor, which is overexpressed in HER2-positive breast cancer, and can be effective in treating breast cancer that has become resistant to trastuzumab.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sorafenib is a kinase inhibitor that is primarily used for the treatment of advanced liver cancer and kidney cancer. It works by blocking the activity of several proteins that promote the growth and spread of cancer cells.

 

Option C. Vismodegib is a hedgehog pathway inhibitor that is used for the treatment of basal cell carcinoma, a type of skin cancer. It works by blocking the hedgehog signalling pathway, which is involved in the development and growth of cancer cells.

 

Option D. Erlotinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor that is used for the treatment of non-small cell lung cancer, pancreatic cancer, and other types of cancer. It works by blocking the activity of the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR), which is involved in the growth and spread of cancer cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lapatinib is an effective treatment for HER2-positive breast cancer, especially in cases where the cancer has become resistant to trastuzumab. It works by targeting the HER2 receptor and can help manage this specific type of breast cancer.

questions.text: The Thymus gland is specialized in identifying the molecules of the Major Histocompatibility Complex that are presented to it. It discerns whether these cells belong to the body's own or are of foreign origin. Which specific gene is accountable for this function? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) AIRE

 

Autoimmunity refers to immune reactions against self-antigens. Normal persons are unresponsive (tolerant) to their own (self) antigens, and autoimmunity results from a failure of self-tolerance.

 

Self-tolerance involves two broad mechanisms: Central Tolerance and Peripheral Tolerance.

 

AIRE (Autoimmune regulator) stimulates expression of some peripheral tissue-restricted self-antigens in the thymus and is critical for deletion of immature T cells specific for these self-antigens. Mutations in the AIRE gene are the cause of an autoimmune polyendocrinopathy.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. NOTCH1: NOTCH1 plays a role in cell growth and division (proliferation), maturation (differentiation), and self-destruction (apoptosis).

 

Option B. E2A: E2A proteins function by recruiting proteins that drive epigenetic remodeling that precedes transcription.

 

Option C. Rag ½: Recombination-activating genes RAG 1 and RAG 2 initiate the molecular processes that lead to lymphocyte receptor formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The AIRE gene is crucial for promoting self-tolerance by ensuring that developing T cells in the thymus are exposed to self-antigens, thus preventing autoimmune diseases.

questions.text: Which metal causes the endemic peripheral vascular disease known as Blackfoot disease?(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Arsenic

 

  • Arsenic, cadmium, lead and mercury are the heavy metals which can cause peripheral vascular disease due to chronic poisoning. This leads to general clinical features of peripheral vascular disease (numbness in feet, rest pain etc.).
  • Blackfoot disease is a unique term given to peripheral vascular disease produced by chronic Arsenic poisoning. The name "Blackfoot" refers to the characteristic darkening and gangrene of the feet and lower legs. This ultimately leads to amputation.
  • In peripheral vascular disease caused by other heavy metals, gangrene is not a common manifestation
  • Below picture shows Blackfoot disease:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Antimony: Antimony does not cause Blackfoot disease. It can cause other toxic effects but is not specifically linked to peripheral vascular disease.

 

Option C. Barium: Barium toxicity is primarily associated with gastrointestinal and muscular symptoms rather than peripheral vascular disease.

 

Option D. Cadmium: While cadmium can cause peripheral vascular disease, it does not specifically lead to Blackfoot disease, which is uniquely associated with arsenic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blackfoot disease, characterized by darkening and gangrene of the feet and lower legs, is specifically caused by chronic arsenic poisoning. Other heavy metals such as cadmium, lead, and mercury can cause peripheral vascular disease, but Blackfoot disease is unique to arsenic exposure.

questions.text: Match the following: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-d, 2-b, 3-c, 4-a

 

 

Silicosis (1-d): Silicosis is an occupational lung disease caused by the inhalation of silica dust, often found in industries like mining, sandblasting, and stone cutting. The term "crazy pavement" refers to a radiologic pattern seen in acute silicosis, which involves interstitial thickening and nodular fibrosis.

 

Mesothelioma (2-b): Mesothelioma is a malignant tumor of the pleura, most commonly associated with asbestos exposure. It typically presents with a pleural effusion that does not cause a mediastinal shift, distinguishing it from other causes of pleural effusion.

 

Caplan syndrome (3-c): Caplan syndrome is a combination of rheumatoid arthritis and pneumoconiosis (particularly coal workers' pneumoconiosis, also known as anthracosis). It was first identified in coal workers.

 

Asbestosis (4-a): Asbestosis is a lung disease resulting from the inhalation of asbestos fibers. It primarily affects the lower (basal) lobes of the lungs and can lead to fibrosis and increased risk of lung cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following options is incorrectly matched? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cystocele - Colposuspension

 

Anterior colporrhaphy is performed for cystocele.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

For cystocele, the appropriate surgical management is anterior colporrhaphy, not colposuspension.

choices.text: Collarette scale - Christmas tree pattern - Pityriasis rosea

questions.text: A young male, aged 24, has presented with asymptomatic scaly skin lesions on his back, symmetrically distributed. The provided images showcase the lesions. Can you identify the pattern of these skin lesions & the specific disease? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Collarette scale - Christmas tree pattern - Pityriasis rosea

 

Given clinical scenario and images showing Collarette scale (Herald patch) and Christmas tree pattern distributed lesions, points to a diagnosis of Pityriasis rosea.

 

PITYRIASIS ROSEA

 

  • Acute: Self-limiting (6-12 weeks) disease.
  • Etiology: Most common viral trigger is HHV 7.
  • Asymptomatic >> mild pruritus may be present.
  • Features:
    • 1st lesion: Herald patch / mother patch 1-2 weeks later.
    • Secondary lesions: Scaly papules → oval annular plaques → mild pigmentary changes → fades slowly in 6-12 weeks.
  • Distribution of Lesions: Christmas tree pattern (Downwards & outwards from the spine along the lines of Langer).
  • Treatment: Counsel, self-limiting 6-12 weeks.

 

Other Options

 

Option B: Wickham’s striae - Lichen Planus

 

  • Incorrect: Lichen Planus is characterized by pruritic, purple, polygonal papules and plaques. Wickham’s striae are white, lacy lines seen on the surface of lesions, typically not featuring a Christmas tree pattern.

 

 

Option C: Christmas tree pattern - Lichen Planus

 

  • Incorrect: While Lichen Planus can have a wide distribution, it does not typically display a Christmas tree pattern, which is specifically associated with Pityriasis rosea.

 

Option D: Wornoff ring – Seborrheic Dermatitis

 

  • Incorrect: Seborrheic Dermatitis typically presents with oily, scaly patches on the scalp, face, and other sebaceous areas, not as a Christmas tree pattern on the back.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnosis of Pityriasis rosea is primarily based on the characteristic appearance and distribution of the rash, with the herald patch and subsequent Christmas tree pattern being hallmark features. Awareness of this pattern and the self-limiting nature of the disease helps in reassuring patients and managing expectations regarding the course of the condition

choices.text: Epithelial cells covered by bacteria
Gardenella vaginalis with Bacillin rods
Doderlein bacili in the macrophage

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes in with a grayish-white vaginal discharge. Upon conducting a gram stain of the discharge, clue cells are observed. What are clue cells? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Epithelial cells covered by bacteria

 

Clue cells are epithelial cells that are covered by bacteria, which gives them a distinctive appearance. In the context of bacterial vaginosis, these cells appear with a fuzzy or irregular border due to the presence of small gram-negative bacilli adhering to their surface. The presence of clue cells is a hallmark of bacterial vaginosis, a condition caused by an imbalance in the normal vaginal flora.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Degranulated neutrophils: Degranulated neutrophils are not clue cells. Neutrophils are involved in the immune response, and their degranulation refers to the release of granules that contain enzymes and other substances. They do not have the fuzzy appearance characteristic of clue cells.

 

Option C. Gardenella vaginalis with Bacillin rods: Gardenella vaginalis is a bacterium associated with bacterial vaginosis, but clue cells are not specifically Gardenella vaginalis with Bacillin rods. Clue cells are epithelial cells covered by various types of bacteria, not a specific bacterium or rod-shaped bacteria.

 

Option D. Doderlein bacilli in the macrophage: Doderlein bacilli (lactobacilli) are normally present in the vagina and help maintain a healthy environment. They are not found within macrophages, nor are they related to the appearance of clue cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clue cells are epithelial cells covered by bacteria, and their presence is indicative of bacterial vaginosis.

questions.text: What are the tactile hallucinations observed in instances of prolonged cocaine intoxication? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Formication

 

Formication, characterized by the feeling of insects moving beneath the skin, is a notable occurrence in cases of cocaine abuse. This phenomenon is also commonly denoted as Magnan's syndrome or cocaine bugs.

 

COCAINE

 

  • Derived from the plant, Erythroxylum coca
  • Sigmund Freud studied its pharmacological effects and probably had an addiction to cocaine too.
  • Was initially used as a local anaesthetic (as it blocks fast sodium channels), especially for ENT surgeries.
  • Blocks dopamine and norepinephrine receptors (dopamine & NE reuptake is inhibited) resulting in-
    • Vasoconstriction: HTN, MI
    • Nasal septal perforation (nasal inhalation of cocaine results in nasal congestion and long-term use can cause nasal septal perforation)
    • Seizures
    • Jet black pigmentation of tongue
  • Routes of administration - Snorting (inhalation of finely powdered form into the nose), freebasing (smoking), I.V. and subcutaneous.

 

Intoxication

 

  • Euphoria
  • Sympathetic symptoms (tachycardia, palpitations, hypertension, sweating, mydriasis)
  • Paranoid ideations (persecutory ideations) + auditory hallucinations
  • Tactile hallucinations or cocaine bugs or magnan phenomenon or formication (sensation of insects crawling under the skin)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oneroid state is a dream-like fantastic delusional derangement of consciousness

 

Option C. Dipsomania is a historical term describing a medical condition involving an uncontrollable craving for alcohol or drugs.

 

Option D. Carphologia is a lint-picking behavior that is often a symptom of a delirious state.

questions.text: Match the following : (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 1-B, 2-A, 3-C, 4-D
 

Explanation:

 

  1. Facial nerve - B. Taste from anterior two-thirds of the tongue: The facial nerve (CN VII) is responsible for carrying taste sensations from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. It also controls the muscles of facial expression.
  2. Spinal accessory nerve - A. Shrugging of the shoulder: The spinal accessory nerve (CN XI) innervates the trapezius muscle, which is responsible for actions such as shrugging the shoulder and scapula elevation. It also contributes to head rotation.
  3. Glossopharyngeal nerve - C. Taste from the posterior one-third of the tongue: The glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) carries taste sensations from the posterior one-third of the tongue. It also plays a role in swallowing and provides sensory information from the throat and tonsils.
  4. Mandibular nerve - D. Chewing: The mandibular nerve (V3) is a branch of the trigeminal nerve (CN V) and is responsible for innervating the muscles of mastication (chewing), as well as providing sensory input to the lower jaw, teeth, and gums.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: In a Pulmonary Function Test at what volume or capacity does the pressure measured at the upper airway reach zero?(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Functional residual capacity

 

  • The functional residual capacity is the volume of the air that remains in the lungs after normal expiration. It is measured by a spirometer.
  • FRC → ERV + RV
  • At the lung volume corresponding to functional residual capacity (FRC), the lungs are in a relaxed state, and the pressure inside them becomes virtually negligible.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Residual volume: Incorrect. Residual volume is the amount of air remaining in the lungs after a maximal exhalation, but it does not correspond to the point where airway pressure is zero.

 

Option C. Total lung capacity: Incorrect. Total lung capacity is the maximum amount of air the lungs can hold, which includes all lung volumes, but it does not correspond to zero airway pressure.

 

Option D. Inspiratory capacity: Incorrect. Inspiratory capacity is the maximum amount of air that can be inhaled after a normal expiration, but it does not correspond to zero airway pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Functional residual capacity is the lung volume at which the pressure in the upper airway reaches zero, indicating a relaxed state of the lungs.

choices.text: Dark ground microscopy

questions.text: A pregnant female visited the obstetrics and gynecology outpatient department (OBG OPD) for her regular prenatal examination. Her past pregnancy involved a stillbirth at 28 weeks. She has a history of engaging in sexual relations with multiple partners and recalls a painless sore on her vulva before her previous pregnancy. What initial investigative step should be taken for this patient? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) VDRL

 

The given scenario with a pregnant female has a history of stillbirth and painless genital ulcer is suggestive of Syphilis. So, Venereal disease research laboratory test (VDRL test) will be the first investigation to be done.

 

SYPHILIS IN PREGNANCY

 

  • Caused by Treponema pallidum
  • Primary Syphilis – Characterized by painless, nontender, single papule over the genitalia, that rapidly becomes eroded and usually becomes indurated, and is called a hard chancre.
  • Kassowitz Law – gradually improving fetal outcomes in congenital syphilis
  • Screening test – VDRL (done for all antenatal patients; May be false positive)
  • USG: FGR, hepatomegaly, fetal anemia, hydrops, placentomegaly
  • Treatment – Benzathine penicillin 2.4 million U

 

Other options:

 

Option A. HIV ELISA: HIV ELISA is done routinely for screening antenatal patients.

 

Option C. Dark ground microscopy: Dark ground microscopy is done when an active ulcer is present.

 

Option D. Culture: Treponema pallidum can’t be cultured. It is not the preferred method to diagnose or screen syphilis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a pregnant woman with a history of stillbirth and a painless genital ulcer, the initial investigation should be the VDRL test to screen for syphilis, as syphilis can significantly impact pregnancy outcomes and requires prompt treatment.

questions.text:
Order in which the following heart sounds are heard from superior to inferior on the left side chest wall? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

1.Pulmonary area

2.Erb’s area

3.Mitral area
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1 → 2 → 3

 

The heart sounds are heard in the following order from superior to inferior on the left side chest wall:

 

Pulmonary area: 2nd intercostal space near the sternum →Erb’s area (2nd aortic area): 3rd intercostal space near the sternum → Mitral area: 4th intercostal space at the midclavicular line (away from sternum).


Educational Objective:

 

The correct order from superior to inferior for heart sounds on the left side chest wall is pulmonary area, Erb’s area, and mitral area.

questions.text: Which of the following pairs is incorrectly matched? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Diagnostic Study - CONSORT

 

  • The reporting standards employed for presenting the outcomes of Randomized Controlled Trials (RCTs) are known as CONSORT, which stands for Consolidated Standards of Reporting Trials.
  • CONSORT (Consolidated Standards of Reporting Trials) is intended for reporting the outcomes of randomized controlled trials (RCTs), not diagnostic studies.
  • The correct reporting guidelines for diagnostic studies are STARD (Standards for Reporting of Diagnostic Accuracy).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Observational study – MOOSE: MOOSE is Meta-analyses Of Observational Studies in Epidemiology

 

Option B. Systematic review – PRISMA: The Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) statement (2009) helps systematic reviewers transparently report why the review was done, what the authors did, and what they found.

 

Option D. Case report – CARE: The CARE guidelines (for CAse REports) were developed by an international group of experts to support an increase in the accuracy, transparency, and usefulness of case reports.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Note - More reporting guidelines can be found on Equator network

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman experiences a 2-year history of infertility, as well as experiencing dyspareunia and dysmenorrhea. She has a retroverted uterus and is sensitive in the Douglas pouch. What should be the subsequent course of action in her management? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) TVS

 

In this case, the initial step in the diagnostic evaluation of suspected endometriosis is transvaginal ultrasound (TVS). TVS is the first-line imaging modality used to assess pelvic structures and identify abnormalities such as endometriomas or nodularity in the pouch of Douglas. While laparoscopy is the gold standard for diagnosing endometriosis and allows for direct visualization and biopsy, it is generally reserved for cases where non-invasive methods are inconclusive or when surgical intervention is planned. TVS provides valuable initial information and helps in guiding further diagnostic and therapeutic steps.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diagnostic laparoscopy: Although laparoscopy is the definitive diagnostic procedure for endometriosis, it is not typically the first step. TVS is preferred initially to assess the presence of endometriosis-related changes and determine if more invasive procedures are necessary.

 

Option B. Laparotomy: Laparotomy is a more invasive surgical approach generally reserved for cases requiring larger abdominal incisions or when laparoscopy is not feasible. It is not typically used as an initial diagnostic tool for endometriosis.

 

Option C. HSG (Hysterosalpingography): HSG is used primarily to evaluate the patency of the fallopian tubes and uterine cavity. While it can assess tubal factor infertility, it does not provide information specific to endometriosis or the pelvic structures affected by it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first step in the management of suspected endometriosis is to perform transvaginal ultrasound (TVS) to evaluate pelvic structures and identify abnormalities.

questions.text: Identify the organism in the given image. (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mucor

 

Histopathological staining shows broad septate, hyaline hyphae with wide angle branching, which suggests that it is more likely Mucor.

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Aspergillus: Aspergillus shows aseptate narrow hyphae with acute angle branching.

 

Option C. Talaromyces: Talaromyces is a genus of fungi that forms septate hyphae and conidiophores.

 

Option D. Blastomyces: Blastomyces dermatitidis is a dimorphic fungus that appears as broad-based budding yeast in tissue sections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mucor is identified by broad aseptate hyaline hyphae with wide-angle branching, and it typically lacks rhizoids, unlike Rhizopus which has nodal rhizoids.

questions.text: After visiting a village temple with his grandmother, a 5-year-old boy began crying intensely during the return trip. Within three hours, he was brought to the emergency department. He displayed symptoms such as altered consciousness, cold and sweaty extremities, heightened salivation, and excessive sweating. Physical examination revealed paleness and priapism, along with vital signs as follows: blood pressure of 140/78 mmHg, heart rate of 152 beats per minute, respiratory rate of 36 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%. Considering his condition, what treatment approach would you choose for his management? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Prazosin

 

This is a case of scorpion bite. The key characteristic feature of scorpion bite is autonomic storm, and sometimes cholinergic storm. This subject is having the features of both storms as described below.

 

Scorpion Toxins affect various ion channels. By acting on sodium (excitation) and potassium (blocking) channels, the toxin prolongs depolarization at postsynaptic postganglionic nerve terminals of ANS. This cause a massive release of sympathetic and parasympathetic mediators, resulting in mixed neuroexcitatory syndrome.

 

Clinical Manifestations of Scorpion bite: Main manifestation of scorpion bite is adrenergic (autonomic storm). Sometimes Cholinergic (muscarinic) storm occurs.

 

  • Adrenergic Storm: Overstimulation of sympathetic system result in “adrenergic storm” which consists of cardiac (tachycardia, peripheral vasoconstriction, hypertension, diaphoresis), metabolic (hyperthermia, hyperglycaemia), urogenital (urinary retention), respiratory (bronchial dilation, tachypnea), and neuromuscular (mydriasis, tremor, agitation, convulsions).

 

  • Cholinergic syndrome: Overstimulation of parasympathetic system result in a hypersecretion syndrome (salivation, sweating, vomiting, urinary incontinence, bronchial hypersecretion, and diarrhea), abdominal pain, miosis, bronchospasm, bradycardia with hypotension and, in the male, priapism.

 

Management:

 

  • Prazosin–a post-synaptic alpha1, adreno-receptor antagonist–is the first line of management. It suppresses sympathetic outflow and activates K channels.
  • Scorpion Antivenom: Scorpion venom act very fast. Anti-venom has to be given within 30 minutes of sting to be effective. So anti-venom is useful only in limited cases which present very early.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Anti-snake venom: Not useful in scorpion bite

 

Option B) Methylprednisolone:  Steroids are not useful in scorpion bite, and moreover steroids might enhance the necrotizing effects of catecholamines on myocardium.

 

Option D) Adrenaline: It will further worsen autonomic storm

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prazosin is the first-line treatment for scorpion envenomation due to its ability to suppress sympathetic outflow and mitigate the effects of the autonomic storm.

questions.text:
Which of the following are true about subclinical myocarditis? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Palpitations
  2. Elevated BNP Troponins
  3. Regional wall motion abnormalities in echo
  4. ECG suggestive of myocarditis
  5. Low LVEF in echo
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2,3,4,5


Subclinical myocarditis may not present with symptoms like palpitations, but can show:

 

2. Elevated BNP/Troponins: Indicating myocardial injury.

3. Regional wall motion abnormalities: Seen on echocardiography.

4. ECG changes: Suggestive of myocarditis, such as non-specific ST-T changes.

5. Low LVEF: Indicative of impaired left ventricular function.

 

Other Option:
 

1. Palpitations are not a feature of subclinical myocarditis.
 

Educational Objective:

 

Subclinical myocarditis can present with elevated cardiac biomarkers, regional wall motion abnormalities, ECG changes, and reduced LVEF, but not Palpitations, which is common in viral myocarditis.

 

Past common causes of myocarditis: Coxsackie virus types A and B.

 

 

Currently, Most common cause of myocarditis: Parvovirus B19 and HHV6.

choices.text: Category A - Easily transmitted and are associated with high mortality rates
Category D - Re-emerging diseases that are high priority agents
Category C - Emerging diseases that are easy to disseminate and are associated with high mortality rates
Category B - Slow to disseminate and are associated with low mortality rates

questions.text: According to the CDC classification of bioterrorism agents, which one of the following statements is untrue? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Category D - Re-emerging diseases that are high priority agents

 

  • As per the CDC, bioterrorism agents are categorized solely into three groups, namely Category A, B, and C, with no classification for a Category D.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Greenish discoloration in right iliac fossa is the earliest sign of decomposition.
In cases of drowning, postmortem hypostasis is seen only in lower limbs.
Adipocere is seen in bodies recovered from water source.
Cadaveric spasm is seen only in specific group of muscles.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about postmortem changes? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. In cases of drowning, postmortem hypostasis is seen only in lower limbs.

 

Postmortem hypostasis occurs in dependent parts. In drowning, the body floats with face down, buttocks up, legs and arms hanging down in front of the body as shown below:

 

 

Hence, in drowning the postmortem staining occurs over face, neck, front of upper part of chest, upper and lower limbs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Greenish discoloration in right iliac fossa is the earliest sign of decomposition: Greenish discoloration after death occurs due to sulfmethemoglobin.

 

Earliest external sign of decomposition: greenish discoloration of right iliac fossa

 

Earliest internal sign of putrefaction: reddish brown discoloration of aorta followed by greenish discoloration of undersurface of liver.

 

Option C. Adipocere is seen in bodies recovered from water source: Adipocere formation requires presence of moisture, hence found in bodies recovered from water.

 

Option D. Cadaveric spasm is seen only in specific group of muscles: Cadaveric spasm is the localized sustained contraction of a specific set of muscles which were used profusely just before death. There is no primary relaxation phase and these muscles become stiff and rigid immediately after death. For example, in case of death due to drowning, if the person grabs hold of grass, then immediately after death, he would be having a clenched fist with some grass in it. On the contrary rigor mortis occurs in all the body muscles gradually.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Postmortem hypostasis occurs in dependent parts of the body based on the position at the time of death. In drowning cases, it affects the face, neck, chest, and limbs, not just the lower limbs.

choices.text: The ratio of the median lethal dose to the median effective dose in an individual.
The range of doses at which a drug is effective without causing significant adverse effects.
The ratio of the median lethal dose to the median effective dose in a population.
The dosage at which a drug is both safe and effective in the majority of patients.

questions.text: Clinical Therapeutic Index of a drug is best described as: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. The ratio of the median lethal dose to the median effective dose in a population.

 

The Clinical Therapeutic Index of a drug is best described as the ratio of the median lethal dose (LD50) to the median effective dose (ED50). Both LD50 and ED50 are calculated by checking different doses in a population.

 

  • It represents the margin of safety of a drug. A higher Clinical Therapeutic Index indicates that a drug has a greater margin of safety, and can be given at higher doses without causing significant adverse effects.
  • The Clinical Therapeutic Index is an important consideration in the development and use of new medications, and helps healthcare providers determine the appropriate dose for individual patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The ratio of the median lethal dose to the median effective dose in an individual: This description is incorrect because the therapeutic index is determined based on population data, not individual data.

 

Option B. The range of doses at which a drug is effective without causing significant adverse effects: This describes the therapeutic window or therapeutic range, not the therapeutic index.

 

Option D. The dosage at which a drug is both safe and effective in the majority of patients: This is a general description of an effective and safe dosage regimen but does not specifically describe the therapeutic index.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Clinical Therapeutic Index of a drug is the ratio of the median lethal dose (LD50) to the median effective dose (ED50) in a population, representing the drug's margin of safety. A higher Therapeutic Index indicates a greater margin of safety.

choices.text: Platelets is stored between 20°c to 24°C with a shelf life of 5 days
Cryoprecipitate is stored at -20°C with a shelf life of 6 months
Packed red cells stored with adenine, glucose, mannitol and saline is stored between -5°C to -15 °C with a shelf life of 5 weeks
Fresh frozen plasma is stored between -5°C to -15° C with a shelf life of 2 years

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about blood products? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Platelets is stored between 20° C to 24° C with a shelf life of 5 days

 

Platelets can be stored at temperatures ranging from 20°C to 24°C, and they have a shelf life of 5 days (with continuous agitation) 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cryoprecipitate is stored at -20°C with a shelf life of 6 months: This statement is incorrect because cryoprecipitate is typically stored at temperatures between -18°C to -30°C with a shelf life of 1 year. Cryoprecipitate is rich in clotting factors like fibrinogen, Factor VIII, and von Willebrand factor.

 

Option C. Packed red cells stored with adenine, glucose, mannitol, and saline is stored between -5°C to -15°C with a shelf life of 5 weeks: This statement is incorrect. Packed red blood cells stored with solutions like SAGM (Saline, Adenine, Glucose, Mannitol) are typically stored at temperatures between 2°C to 6°C, not -5°C to -15°C, and they have a shelf life of up to 42 days, not 5 weeks.

 

Option D. Fresh frozen plasma is stored between -5°C to -15°C with a shelf life of 2 years: This statement is incorrect. Fresh frozen plasma (FFP) is usually stored at temperatures between -18°C to -30°C and has a shelf life of 1 year.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-coagulants solution and shelf life

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with non-small cell lung carcinoma (NSCLC). Molecular testing reveals a specific mutation in the EGFR gene. The oncologist is considering using targeted therapy. For which of the following EGFR mutations is Osimertinib most appropriately used to treat non-small cell lung carcinoma? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. T790M mutation

 

Osimertinib is a third-generation epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) tyrosine kinase inhibitor (TKI) that is particularly effective in treating non-small cell lung carcinoma (NSCLC) patients who have developed resistance to first-generation EGFR inhibitors (such as gefitinib or erlotinib) due to the T790M mutation in the EGFR gene. This mutation is a common mechanism of acquired resistance, and Osimertinib is specifically designed to target it.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. L858R mutation is another common EGFR mutation seen in NSCLC. Although Osimertinib can also be used for L858R mutations, it is not specifically indicated as the primary treatment for this mutation. First-generation EGFR inhibitors like gefitinib or erlotinib are often used for L858R mutations.

 

Option C. T890M mutation and Option D. M790T mutation are not recognized mutations associated with EGFR in the context of NSCLC, and there is no evidence to suggest that Osimertinib is used for these mutations.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: After the administration of phenylephrine, the depicted images reveal an observed alteration. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nodular episcleritis

 

Upon the application of phenylephrine, the superficial episcleral vessels lose their color, a phenomenon known as blanching. As a result, the likely conclusion is nodular episcleritis.

 

2.5% phenylephrine proves valuable in distinguishing between episcleritis and scleritis. This distinction arises from the fact that the vessels within the episclera lie close to the surface, making them susceptible to blanching. In contrast, in cases of scleritis, these vessels do not undergo such a color change.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nodular Scleritis: Scleritis involves deeper layers of the eye and is typically more painful. Vessels in scleritis do not blanch with phenylephrine due to their depth and the severity of inflammation.

 

Option C. Tenon's Cyst: This refers to a cystic lesion involving Tenon's capsule, not typically associated with the superficial vascular changes seen in episcleritis.

 

Option D. Nodular Phlycten: This is a small, nodular inflammatory lesion usually at the corneal limbus, often related to an immune response to bacterial proteins, particularly from staphylococcal or tubercular origins, not showing the same response to phenylephrine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Episcleritis can typically be diagnosed based on its clinical appearance and response to phenylephrine. The ability of phenylephrine to cause blanching of the inflamed episcleral vessels is a useful diagnostic tool, helping to differentiate episcleritis from more serious conditions like scleritis, where the inflammation involves deeper tissues and the vessels do not blanch.

questions.text: An individual experienced a dog bite. Both the person and the dog are up-to-date with their vaccinations. The person's medical history includes a splenectomy performed five years ago. What is the optimal course of action for managing this situation? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Amoxiclav

 

  • Amoxicillin/clavulanate (Augmentin) is generally considered the first-line prophylactic treatment for animal bites.
  • Appropriate tetanus and rabies prophylaxis as indicated should also be a part of caring for a patient who has sustained a dog bite, as well as local debridement and thorough cleaning of the wound

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Observation: Observation alone is not sufficient due to the risk of infection, especially in an asplenic individual.

 

Option C. Metronidazole: This antibiotic is not typically used as monotherapy for animal bites as it does not cover the range of bacteria commonly involved.

 

Option D. Ciprofloxacin: While it has some coverage, it is not the first-line treatment for dog bites and lacks the broad coverage provided by amoxicillin/clavulanate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Amoxicillin/clavulanate is the optimal course of action for prophylactic treatment following a dog bite, especially in individuals with increased infection risk, such as those with a history of splenectomy.
  • Thorough wound care and appropriate prophylaxis for tetanus and rabies should also be part of the management plan.

questions.text: The base sequence of the strand of DNA used as the template for transcription has the base sequence 5'GATCTAC3'. What is the base sequence of RNA product? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 5'GUAGAUC3'

 

Explanation:

 

You're given the template strand of DNA:


5′–GATCTAC–3′

 

But remember:

 

  • Transcription reads the DNA template in the 3′ → 5′ direction
  • So we must first reverse the strand to get its 3′ → 5′ orientation
    3′–CATAGTC–5′

 

Now, perform complementary base pairing to make the RNA strand (synthesized 5′ to 3′):

 

 

So the RNA product is:


5′–GUAGAUC–3′

 

Educational Objective

 

The complementary base pairing rules are:

 

  • Adenine (A) pairs with Uracil (U) in RNA.
  • Thymine (T) pairs with Adenine (A).
  • Cytosine (C) pairs with Guanine (G).
  • Guanine (G) pairs with Cytosine (C).

 

The RNA product formed during transcription is complementary to the DNA template strand and follows the base-pairing rules with uracil replacing thymine.

choices.text: Initially growth of the tumor was away from the joint, now the growth of tumor is towards the joint.
Tumor does not have malignant transformation potential.
Tumor is in continuation with bone marrow cavity of the normal bone.
Hyaline cap thickness on MRI is 2cms.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy came with a tumor resembling a mushroom in the distal femur, which has been present for the last two years. What characteristics should the clinician look for to discern a potential malignant transformation? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Hyaline cap thickness on MRI is 2cms.

 

  • The provided X-ray reveals a clearly defined exostosis, indicating a diagnosis of osteochondroma.
  • Additionally, the hyaline cap thickness of 2cms observed on the MRI raises concerns about the possibility of malignant transformation.

 

OSTEOCHONDROMA

 

  • Osteochondroma is the commonest benign “tumour” of the bone.
  • It is not a true neoplasm since its growth stops with cessation of growth at the epiphyseal plate.
  • It is the developmental malformation thought to originate within the periosteum as small cartilaginous nodules.
  • X-ray shows an osseous outgrowth arising from the medial aspect of the distal femur and directed upwards (away from the joint), its cortex appears continuous with that of the femur.
  • Osteochondroma shows a bone with cartilage cap that is irregular and usually cannot be seen on radiographs, a result of development malformation.
  • Occasionally, calcification within the cap may be seen which usually angle away from the growth plate.
  • Typically, the cap is only a few millimeters thick in adults, although it may be 2 cm thick in a child.
  • An osseus outgrowth grows away from bone and grows till skeletal maturity.
  • Osteochondromas are found on the metaphysis of a long bone near the physis.
  • They are seen most often on the distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus.
  • Many of these lesions cause no symptoms and are discovered incidentally.
  • Pain may be present due to bursitis or malignant transformation.
  • Malignant transformation should be suspected when a previously quiescent lesion in an adult grows rapidly; has enlarged further after skeletal maturity, there is loss of corticomedullary differentiation.
  • It usually takes the form of a low-grade chondrosarcoma.
  • In these cases, the cartilage cap usually is more than 2 cm thick. (Best evaluated by MRI).
  • Osteochondromas are of two types: Pedunculated and broad- based or sessile.
  • Pedunculated tumors are more common. The stalk is directed away from the physis adjacent to which it takes its origin. The projecting part of the lesion has cortical and cancellous components, both of which are continuous with the parent bone.
  • The lesion is covered by a cartilaginous cap
  • Treatment: 
    • Surgery (en bloc resection-extraperiosteal resection) is indicated for lesion that causes pain, symptomatic impingement on neurovascular structure, compromise of joint function, cosmetic deformity, painful bursa formation and rapid increase in size of lesion or when imaging features suggest malignancy.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Initially growth of the tumor was away from the joint, now the growth of tumor is towards the joint. This is not true for an osteochondroma. The lesion is covered by a cartilaginous cap which is irregular and usually grows away from the growth plate.

 

Option B. Tumor does not have malignant transformation potential. This is not true. The incidence of malignant degeneration is approximately 1% for patients with a solitary osteochondroma and 6% for patients with multiple hereditary exostoses. Malignant transformation should be suspected when a previously quiescent lesion in an adult grows rapidly; any further enlargement after skeletal maturity takes place, loss of corticomedullary differentiation takes place. It usually takes the form of a low-grade chondrosarcoma. In these cases, the cartilage cap usually is more than 2 cm thick which can be best evaluated by MRI).

 

Option C. Tumor is in continuation with bone marrow cavity of the normal bone. This is not true. The stalk of the lesion grows away from the physis, adjacent to which it takes its origin. The projecting part of the lesion has cortical and cancellous components, both of which are continuous with the corresponding components of the parent bone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The malignant transformation of osteochondroma is suspected when the hyaline cap thickness is 2cm, as seen on the MRI.

questions.text: During which phase of the cardiac cycle is an AR murmur likely to be heard? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ventricular diastole


Aortic regurgitation (AR) murmurs are classic early diastolic murmurs heard during ventricular diastole, when blood flows back into the left ventricle from the aorta.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Ventricular ejection: Associated with systolic murmurs.
 

Option B. Throughout cardiac cycle: Associated with continuous murmurs, like in PDA.
 

Option C. Isovolumetric contraction: Not typically associated with murmurs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aortic regurgitation murmurs are heard during ventricular diastole

choices.text: Total lack of natural killer cells
Decrease in lgG and increase in lgM
Inability of neutrophils to fight against infections

questions.text: Which of the subsequent statements accurately describes the immunological anomaly associated with the absence of CD40 in B cells? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decrease in lgG and increase in lgM

 

The absence of CD40 and its deficiency in B cells results in Hyper IgM syndrome. This condition is characterized by a reduction in IgG levels and an elevation in IgM levels.

 

HYPER IGM SYNDROME

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Total lack of natural killer cells: This is not associated with CD40 deficiency but rather with other immune disorders like severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID).

 

Option B. Lack of CD8 mediated cytotoxicity: CD40/CD40L interactions do not directly affect CD8 T cells. CD8 mediated cytotoxicity is more related to T cell receptor function and MHC class I interactions.

 

Option D. Inability of neutrophils to fight against infections: While CD40 deficiency can lead to an increased susceptibility to infections, neutrophil function is not directly impaired by the absence of CD40. This function is more related to chronic granulomatous disease or other neutrophil defects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyper IgM syndrome is characterized by an increased level of IgM and decreased levels of other immunoglobulins like IgG, due to a defect in the CD40/CD40L interaction necessary for immunoglobulin class switching.

questions.text: The microorganism demonstrates resistance to meropenem and aminoglycosides, while being susceptible to ticarcillin-clavulanate and cotrimoxazole. Which microorganism is most likely responsible? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stenotrophomonas maltophila

 

  • Stenotrophomonas maltophila, previously known as Pseudomonas maltophila, is an opportunistic pathogen responsible for wound infections, urinary tract infections, and septicemia.
  • It displays susceptibility to cotrimoxazole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Proteus mirabilis:

 

  • Resistant to: Nitrofurantoin, Tetracyclines
  • Susceptible to aminoglycosides, carbapenems, cephalosporins, cotromoxazole, penicillin+ β-lactamase inhibitors.
  • Clinical manifestations: Respiratory infections, especially in cystic fibrosis patients, and opportunistic infections.

 

Option C. Pseudomonas aeruginosa:

 

  • Known for resistance to multiple antibiotics, but typically not specifically resistant to meropenem.
