  • Susceptible to: A wide range of antibiotics, often including aminoglycosides, depending on the strain.
  • Clinical manifestations: Respiratory infections, wound infections, and urinary tract infections.

 

Option D. Acinetobacter baumannii:

 

  • Known for multi-drug resistance, including to carbapenems like meropenem.
  • Susceptibility varies, but generally not as consistently susceptible to ticarcillin-clavulanate as Stenotrophomonas maltophila.
  • Clinical manifestations: Hospital-acquired infections, such as pneumonia and bloodstream infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stenotrophomonas maltophila is an opportunistic pathogen resistant to meropenem and aminoglycosides but susceptible to ticarcillin-clavulanate and cotrimoxazole.

questions.text:
What procedures are carried out during Breast Conservation Surgery? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Wide local excision
  2. Axillary node dissection
  3. Frozen section (biopsy) to be done during surgery
  4. Post-operative radiotherapy is optional
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3

 

1. Wide local excision:

 

  • This involves the removal of the breast tumor and a margin of surrounding normal tissue. The goal is to ensure that no cancer cells remain at the site, while preserving as much of the breast's appearance and function as possible.

 

2. Axillary node dissection:

 

  • This procedure involves removing lymph nodes from the axilla to check for the spread of cancer. If the sentinel lymph node biopsy (a procedure to remove the first node(s) that breast cancer is likely to spread) shows cancer, more extensive lymph node surgery might be done.

 

3. Frozen section (biopsy) to be done during surgery:

 

  • A frozen section involves rapidly freezing a tissue sample from the patient during surgery. A pathologist then examines the tissue under a microscope. This procedure allows for an immediate diagnosis, which can guide surgical decisions during the procedure, such as whether wider excision is needed if margins are not clear.

 

Other Option:

 

4. Post-operative radiotherapy is optional:

 

  • This statement is incorrect in the context of Breast Conservation Surgery (BCS). Post-operative radiotherapy is essential after BCS to reduce the risk of local recurrence of the tumor in the preserved breast tissue. It is not optional; rather, it's a standard part of the treatment plan in most cases.

 

Breast Conservative Therapy (BCT) consists of:

 

a. Wide local excision (>1cm) of tumor

 

b. Sentinel lymph node biopsy (if clinically node negative)

 

c. Post-operative radiotherapy – given in all cases of BCT

 

d. If pre-operative axillary LN metastasis is present, no need for sentinel lymph node biopsy. Up front axillary lymphadenectomy is done along with wide local excision of tumor.

choices.text: Decreases risk of Colon cancer
Decreased risk of breast cancer
Decreased risk of endometrial cancer

questions.text: Which of the following is a true association with HRT?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Decreases risk of Colon cancer

 

Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT) has been shown to decrease the risk of colon cancer. HRT is often used to manage symptoms of menopause, such as hot flushes and osteoporosis, but it also has some protective effects, including lowering the risk of colon cancer.

 

  • Indications of HRT:
    • Therapeutic: For symptomatic women with estrogen deficiency or specific conditions like gonadal dysgenesis in adolescents.
    • Prophylactic: It is used in high-risk cases, such as preventing menopausal complications like cardiovascular disease, osteoporosis, Alzheimer’s, and colon cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Decreased risk of breast cancer: This is incorrect. HRT, especially when combined (estrogen and progesterone), has been associated with an increased risk of breast cancer.

 

Option C. Decreased risk of endometrial cancer: This is incorrect. Unopposed estrogen therapy (without progesterone) increases the risk of endometrial cancer.

 

Option D. Increases risk of osteoporosis: This is incorrect. HRT actually reduces the risk of osteoporosis, as estrogen helps maintain bone density.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT) decreases the risk of colon cancer but is associated with an increased risk of breast and endometrial cancers.

questions.text: A patient with C/O muscle weakness came to OPD. Doctor found he has cardiomyopathy & diagnosed him to be a case of Barth syndrome, where patient has mitochondrial dysfunction. What is the defect in this patient: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cardiolipin

 

Barth syndrome is a rare genetic disorder that primarily affects males and is caused by mutations in gene responsible for the production of an enzyme involved in cardiolipin synthesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lecithin is a common phospholipid found in various tissues and cell membranes, but it is not specifically associated with Barth syndrome or mitochondrial dysfunction.

 

Option C. Lysolecithin is a derivative of lecithin that is formed when lecithin is hydrolyzed. It is not directly related to Barth syndrome or mitochondrial dysfunction.

 

Option D. Cephalin is a term that refers to a group of phospholipids present in cell membranes, but it is not specifically linked to Barth syndrome or mitochondrial dysfunction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cardiolipin is a unique phospholipid primarily found in the inner mitochondrial membrane, where it plays a crucial role in maintaining mitochondrial structure and function.
  • The defective cardiolipin affects several mitochondrial processes, including energy production, electron transport chain function, and mitochondrial membrane stability. 
  • C/f
    • Muscle weakness
    • Neutropenia
    • Cardiomyopathy

choices.text: Mode is affected by extreme values
Mean is affected by extreme values
Median is calculated by overall observations
Mode can be used as a qualitative data descriptor

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false for descriptors of central tendency? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mode is affected by extreme values

 

  • Extreme values in a given dataset do not influence the mode.
  • Mode is the most frequent or most commonly occurring value in a distribution.
  • It is uninfluenced by extreme values and can be used to describe qualitative data

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mean is affected by extreme values: This is true. Extreme values (outliers) can significantly affect the mean, making it an unreliable measure of central tendency in skewed distributions.

 

Option C. Median is calculated by overall observations: This is true. The median is determined by arranging all observations in order and finding the middle value, or the average of the two middle values if the number of observations is even.

 

Option D. Mode can be used as a qualitative data descriptor: This is true. The mode is applicable to qualitative data as it represents the most frequently occurring category or value.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The mode is not affected by extreme values and can be used to describe qualitative data.
  • In contrast, the mean is affected by extreme values, and the median is a robust measure of central tendency that is calculated using overall observations.

questions.text:
What are the recommended actions according to Neonatal Resuscitation guidelines for a baby born with meconium-stained amniotic fluid? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. lntrapartum suction of nose and mouth before delivery of shoulder
  2. lntratracheal suction in case of non-vigorous baby
  3. Gentle suction of nose and mouth in case of vigorous baby
  4. PPV in case of non-vigorous baby after early steps
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 4


According to the Neonatal Resuscitation guidelines, the recommended actions for a newborn with meconium-stained amniotic fluid are as follows:

 

4. For a non-vigorous baby (poor muscle tone, weak or absent respiratory effort, or heart rate <100 bpm): The baby should receive positive pressure ventilation (PPV) following initial resuscitation steps. The current guidelines recommend PPV over routine intratracheal suctioning in non-vigorous infants because studies have shown that routine suctioning does not improve outcomes and may delay necessary resuscitation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1, 2, 3, 4: Intrapartum suction of the nose and mouth before delivery of the shoulders and routine intratracheal suctioning are no longer recommended in the current guidelines.

 

Option B. 2, 4: While PPV is recommended for non-vigorous infants, routine intratracheal suctioning is not indicated.

 

Option D. 1, 3, 4: Intrapartum suction is not recommended under the current guidelines.

 

Educational Objective:
 

For a newborn with meconium-stained amniotic fluid, PPV is administered if the baby is non-vigorous after the initial steps of resuscitation.

questions.text:
Which of the following muscles form the pelvic diaphragm?(INICET MAY 2023)

 

1. Iliococcygeus

2. Pubococcygeus

3. Obturator internus

4. Deep transverse perinei
questions.solution:
Ans. A.  1, 2

 

The Iliococcygeus and pubococcygeus muscles are components of the pelvic diaphragm, commonly referred to as the levator ani.

 

The pelvic diaphragm is a muscular partition between the true pelvis and the perineum. It is formed by the large levator ani and small coccygeus muscles of two sides and their covering fasciae.

 

 

1. Iliococcygeus: The iliococcygeus is one of the muscles that form the pelvic diaphragm. It is part of the levator ani muscle group. The levator ani consists of the iliococcygeus, pubococcygeus, and puborectalis muscles. The iliococcygeus muscle extends from the ischial spine (a bony projection in the pelvis) to the coccyx (the tailbone) and contributes to the support of the pelvic floor.
 

2. Pubococcygeus: The pubococcygeus muscle is another component of the levator ani muscle group and is a part of the pelvic diaphragm. It extends from the pubic bone to the coccyx and helps maintain pelvic organ support and control.

 

Other Options:

 

3. Obturator Internus: The obturator internus is not considered a part of the pelvic diaphragm. It is a separate muscle located in the pelvic region, and its primary function is to laterally rotate the thigh. While it is near the pelvic diaphragm, it does not contribute to its formation.
 

4. Deep Transverse Perinei: The deep transverse perineal muscles are not typically considered part of the pelvic diaphragm. These muscles are located in the perineum (the area between the anus and the genitalia) and play a role in stabilizing the perineal body and supporting the pelvic organs. They are important for urinary and fecal continence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pelvic diaphragm is formed by the iliococcygeus and pubococcygeus muscles (part of the levator ani muscle group). The obturator internus and deep transverse perineal muscles are nearby but are not considered part of the pelvic diaphragm itself.

choices.text: The trial investigated NSCLC treatment using a combination of pembrolizumab and chemotherapy.
The trial focused solely on the use of pembrolizumab for treating NSCLC.
The study explored the efficacy of combining nivolumab and chemotherapy for NSCLC.
The trial looked at nivolumab as a treatment option for NSCLC.

questions.text: An oncologist is discussing with a colleague about the latest evidence-based approaches to treating non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). The KEYNOTE-189 trial comes up in their conversation. Which of the following accurately describes the focus of the KEYNOTE-189 trial? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. The trial investigated NSCLC treatment using a combination of pembrolizumab and chemotherapy.

 

The KEYNOTE trials are a series of clinical studies investigating the use of pembrolizumab, an immune checkpoint inhibitor, in various types of cancer. Pembrolizumab targets the PD-1 receptor, thereby enabling the immune system to better recognize and attack cancer cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. The trial focused solely on the use of pembrolizumab for treating NSCLC: This is incorrect. The KEYNOTE-189 trial investigated pembrolizumab in combination with chemotherapy, not as a monotherapy.

 

Option C. The study explored the efficacy of combining nivolumab and chemotherapy for NSCLC: This is incorrect. The KEYNOTE-189 trial did not involve nivolumab; it focused on pembrolizumab in combination with chemotherapy.

 

Option D. The trial looked at nivolumab as a treatment option for NSCLC: This is incorrect. The KEYNOTE-189 trial was centered on pembrolizumab, not nivolumab.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 65-year-old man suffering from persistent fatigue and lymph node enlargement visits the outpatient department. Examination of his peripheral smear reveals the presence of smudge cells. To further establish a diagnosis, what additional investigations will you conduct? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Flow cytometry

 

An elderly man presenting with chronic fatigue and lymphadenopathy and revelation of smudge cells on peripheral smear suggests a diagnosis of Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia. Flow cytometry is the investigation of choice.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR): PCR is typically used for detecting specific genetic mutations or translocations but is not the primary diagnostic tool for CLL.

 

Option B. Fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH): FISH is used to detect specific chromosomal abnormalities, such as deletions or translocations. While useful, it is not the first-line investigation for diagnosing CLL.

 

Option D. Cytogenetics: Cytogenetic analysis can reveal chromosomal abnormalities associated with CLL, such as deletion 13q, but is typically used in conjunction with other tests like flow cytometry.

 

Educational Objective:


Flow cytometry is the primary diagnostic tool for confirming Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia, particularly in cases where smudge cells are identified on a peripheral smear.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of reversible dementia? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lewy body dementia


Lewy body dementia is a progressive and irreversible neurodegenerative disorder.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. B12 deficiency: Reversible with supplementation.
 

Option B. Normal pressure hydrocephalus: Reversible with shunting.
 

Option D. Hypothyroidism: Reversible with thyroid hormone replacement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lewy body dementia is not a reversible cause of dementia.

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 28 weeks of gestation is experiencing symptoms of fever, acute abdominal pain, and a slight increase in white blood cell count. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Red degeneration of fibroid

 

RED DEGENERATION OF FIBROID

 

  • Occurs in a large fibroid mainly during second half of pregnancy and puerperium.
  • The cause is not known but is probably due to thrombosis and infarction
  • The typical presentation is severe abdominal pain especially in the 2nd trimester of pregnancy.
  • Treatment is symptomatic with analgesics and hydration
  • TLC is raised but the etiology is not infective
  • Surgery is NOT done for red degeneration
  • Can also happen in the puerperium and in women on combined OCPS

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uterine torsion: Uterine torsion can lead to birth obstruction, abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, shock, and urinary and intestinal symptoms.

 

Option B. Infection of fibroid: Infection of fibroid can cause blood-stained purulent discharge

 

Option D. Preterm labor: Preterm labor doesn’t relate with fever, raised TLC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Red degeneration of fibroid, which typically occurs in the second half of pregnancy or puerperium, presents with severe abdominal pain, fever, and a slight increase in white blood cell count. It is caused by thrombosis and infarction of the fibroid, and treatment is symptomatic with analgesics and hydration. Surgery is not performed for red degeneration.

choices.text: Diet should contain 400 kcal from carbohydrates
Diet should contain 800 kcal from fat

questions.text: What does the FDA say about a diet, high in fat intake? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Diet should contain total 1000 kcal

 

  • According to FDA, high fat diet is a diet having 50% of total caloric content of the meal and a high calorie diet is a diet containing total 1000 kcal.
  • This meal should derive approximately 150, 250, and 500-600 calories from protein, carbohydrate, and fat, respectively

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diet should contain 400 kcal from carbohydrates: Incorrect. While carbohydrates are a part of the diet, this specific statement does not match the FDA's guideline for a high-fat diet.

 

Option C. Diet should contain 800 kcal from fat: Incorrect. A high-fat diet typically derives around 500-600 kcal from fat, not 800 kcal.

 

Option D. Diet should contain 80% fats: Incorrect. A high-fat diet is defined by having around 50% of its caloric content from fats, not 80%.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The FDA defines a high-fat diet as one that has around 50% of its total caloric intake from fats, and a high-calorie diet should contain a total of 1000 kcal.

questions.text: Which sequence of dyes is employed for ocular surface examination and dry eye staining? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fluorescein → Lisssamine green → Rose Bengal

 

The optimal sequence of dyes for ocular surface examination and dry eye staining from the provided choices is as follows: Fluorescein → Lisssamine green → Rose Bengal

 

Fluorescein stain – it is an orange colored dye → stains the defect. Under cobalt blue light, the defect appears green.

 

Rose Bengal stain – stains the dead cells. It causes stinging, so, not very popular, and so applied the last.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The recommended sequence of application—starting with fluorescein, followed by lissamine green, and ending with Rose Bengal—minimizes discomfort and interference between the dyes. Since Rose Bengal can be irritating, it is applied last, after the assessment with the less irritating dyes has been completed.

questions.text:
Organize the subsequent structures in the auditory pathway, beginning from the receptors and moving towards the cortex: (INICET May 2023)

 

  1. Auditory Cortex
  2. Spiral ganglion
  3. Cochlear Nucleus
  4. Lateral leminiscus
  5. Inferior colliculus
  6. Olivary complex
  7. Medial geniculate body
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2-3-6-4-5-7-1

 

The correct sequence of structures in the auditory pathway, beginning from the receptors (cochlea) and moving towards the auditory cortex, is as follows:

 

2. Spiral ganglion: The auditory nerve fibers originate here.

 

3. Cochlear Nucleus: The auditory nerve fibers synapse in the cochlear nuclei located in the brainstem.

 

6. Olivary complex: After the cochlear nucleus, the pathway proceeds to the superior olivary complex.

 

4. Lateral lemniscus: From the superior olivary complex, the auditory signals travel via the lateral lemniscus.

 

5. Inferior colliculus: The lateral lemniscus projects to the inferior colliculus in the midbrain.

 

7. Medial geniculate body: The signals are then relayed to the medial geniculate body of the thalamus.

 

1. Auditory Cortex: Finally, the signals reach the auditory cortex (Area 41) in the temporal lobe for processing.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

AUDITORY PATHWAY

 

E – Eighth nerve

 

C – Cochlear nucleus

 

O – Olivary complex (superior)

 

L – Lateral lemniscus

 

I – Inferior colliculus

 

M – Medial geniculate body

 

A – Auditory cortex

questions.text: A female presented with excessive daytime sleepiness and impaired concentration and memory for one year. On examination the BMI was 43 kg/m² and BP was 170/98 mmHg. ABG was done in awake state and the findings are given below. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis? PaO2: 70 mmHg PaCO2: 53 mmHg HCO3: 33 mmHg. (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Obesity hypoventilation syndrome

 

Obesity hypoventilation syndrome (OHS), also known as Pickwickian syndrome, is characterized by obesity (BMI >30 kg/m²), hypoventilation (PaCO2 >45 mmHg), and lack of significant underlying lung disease. The ABG findings showing hypercapnia (high PaCO2) and hypoxemia (low PaO2) in the awake state are indicative of OHS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Obstructive sleep apnea: Occurs during sleep, not necessarily presenting with hypercapnia in the awake state.
 

Option C. Central sleep apnea: Characterized by pauses in breathing during sleep without the obesity-related hypoventilation.
 

Option D. Narcolepsy: Does not typically present with ABG abnormalities or obesity hypoventilation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Obesity hypoventilation syndrome involves obesity, chronic hypercapnia, and hypoxemia, primarily in the awake state.

questions.text: Given below is an X-ray of shoulder of a 25-year-old male who suffered a shoulder injury and now exhibits swelling around the shoulder joint. Based on the X-ray, which structure(s) is/are probable sites of injury? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Both acromioclavicular and coracoclavicular ligament

 

  • The provided image indicates an upward displacement of the clavicle, accompanied by a noticeable gap between the clavicle and the acromion.
  • This suggests potential injuries to both the acromioclavicular and coracoclavicular ligaments.

 

ACROMIOCLAVICULAR JOINT DISLOCATION

 

  • Acromioclavicular (AC) joint injury typically occurs due to a fall onto the acromion.
  • Stability of the AC joint is dependent upon both the AC and coracoclavicular (CC) ligaments.
  • An acromioclavicular joint separation occurs when the clavicle separates from the scapula.
  • It is commonly caused by a fall directly on the ‘point’ of the shoulder or by a direct blow received in a contact sport.
  • AC Joint separation is almost always the result of a sudden, traumatic event that can be attributed to a specific incident or action.
  • The two most common causes are either a direct blow to the shoulder (seen in football, rugby, or hockey), or a fall on to an outstretched hand (after falling off a bicycle).
  • Symptoms:
    • Pain and swelling around the joint
    • Pain on movement of the arm
    • Depending on the grade, a bump may be present on the top of the shoulder where the clavicle ends
    • The joint may be very unstable
  • It is classified into type 1 to 6 by Rockwood classification according to the severity of the injury and position of the displaced bones.

 

 

 

 

  • Treatment according to the grades include:
    • Type I-III: Conservative management with velpeau bandage. The bandage pushes the lateral end of shoulder downwards and the arm upwards, thus maintaining the reduction.
    • Type IV-VI: Open reduction and internal fixation

 

Other Option:

 

Option C. Coracoacromial ligament. Coracoacromial ligament originates from the medial border of the acromion and attaches to the lateral border of the coracoid process. This ligament forms a part of the coracoacromial arch and provides support to the humeral head. Coracoacromial ligament injury is mostly related to trauma or clavicular fracture and isolated injury to the coracoacromial ligament is rare. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In acromioclavicular joint dislocation or separation, as shown in the image provided in the question, there is tear in the acromioclavicular and coracoclavicular ligaments.

questions.text: A 4-year-old male child arrived with a history of fever, reddened and congested conjunctiva, along with skin exhibiting redness and peeling, as depicted in the provided images. A 2D echocardiogram revealed the presence of a coronary aneurysm. What constitutes the initial course of treatment for this condition? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IVIG

 

The clinical presentation of fever, congested conjunctiva, strawberry tongue, and red skin peeling, along with the echocardiogram finding of a coronary aneurysm, is highly suggestive of Kawasaki disease. Kawasaki disease is a systemic vasculitis that primarily affects children and can lead to coronary artery aneurysms if not treated promptly.

 

Initial Treatment: The mainstay of treatment for Kawasaki disease is the administration of Intravenous Immunoglobulin (IVIG). IVIG is given to reduce the risk of coronary artery aneurysms, which is the most serious complication of Kawasaki disease. The standard dose is 2 g/kg administered as a single infusion, usually within the first 10 days of illness.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Aspirin: Aspirin is also used in the management of Kawasaki disease, typically in conjunction with IVIG. However, IVIG is the first-line treatment to reduce inflammation and prevent coronary complications.

 

Option C. Clopidogrel: Clopidogrel is an antiplatelet agent, but it is not part of the initial treatment for Kawasaki disease.

 

Option D. LMWH: Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH) is an anticoagulant, but it is not used as the primary treatment for Kawasaki disease.

 

Educational Objective:
 

In Kawasaki disease, the initial course of treatment involves the administration of IVIG to reduce the risk of coronary artery aneurysms and other complications.

questions.text: A study involved 30,000 women who were monitored for a period of 10 years to track the occurrence of breast cancer. Among them, 1200 women developed cancer and were subsequently given a questionnaire to evaluate potential risk factors. In parallel, 2000 women from the same study served as controls and were also subjected to the questionnaire. What is the name of this type of study? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nested case control

 

  • Given scenario dictates that a population was monitored for development of breast cancer.
  • Out of which, 1200 women developed breast cancer and a small subgroup was taken as control.
  • This study structure points to Nested case control study.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cohort study: Cohort study involves selecting Exposed and non-exposed groups then follow them for development of outcome.

 

Option B. Retrospective cohort: In Retrospective cohort, the outcomes have already occurred before the study begins.

 

Option D. Cross control cohort: Cross control cohort is not a study design.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A nested case-control study involves identifying cases and controls from an existing cohort that is being followed over time, making it a cost-effective way to study the associations between exposures and outcomes.

questions.text: Match the wood lamp findings with the respective diseases: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-e,2-c,3-d,4-b

 

Erythrasma (1-e): Shows a characteristic coral red fluorescence under Wood's lamp. This fluorescence is due to the production of porphyrins by Corynebacterium minutissimum, the bacteria responsible for erythrasma.

 

Pityriasis versicolor (2-c): Typically displays a yellow fluorescence. The causative yeast, Malassezia, can produce metabolites that fluoresce under a Wood's lamp.

 

Tinea Capitis (3-d): Often shows a blue fluorescence. The fungi causing tinea capitis, like species of Microsporum, can fluoresce blue due to the presence of certain metabolic byproducts in the fungal cell walls.

 

Vitiligo (4-b): Exhibits a milky white fluorescence. This is because the areas affected by vitiligo lack melanin, making the skin appear distinctly brighter under the UV light of a Wood's lamp compared to normal skin.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Wood's lamp is a useful diagnostic tool in dermatology for visualizing certain fungal and bacterial infections, as well as pigmentary disorders. The specific color of fluorescence can guide clinicians in making a preliminary diagnosis, which must be confirmed with additional tests or clinical evaluation.

choices.text: Statement 1 is false and Statement 2 is true
Statement 1 is true and Statement 2 is false
Both the statements are true but 2 is not the conclusion of 1
Both the statements are true and 2 is the conclusion of 1

questions.text:
Statement 1: Clinically a patient having flaccid bullae with painful erosions, will show Suprabasal split and inflammatory infiltrate in the blister cleft on histopathological examination.

 

Statement 2: Row of tombstones appearance is diagnostic of Pemphigus vulgaris (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both the statements are true but 2 is not the conclusion of 1

 

Both statements are true about Pemphigus vulgaris but statement 2 is not explaining 1.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pemphigus vulgaris, a blistering autoimmune skin condition. The condition is characterized by suprabasal acantholysis (a separation of skin cells above the basal cell layer), leading to the formation of flaccid bullae with painful erosions. The "row of tombstones" appearance describes a specific histological feature of Pemphigus vulgaris.

choices.text: Can be used for screening mammographically undetectable or clinically non palpable breast mass
Useful in young females with dense breast
Differentiates between solid and Cystic lesions in the Breast

questions.text: Which of the following isn't considered a benefit of USG compared to Mammography?(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Can be used for screening mammographically undetectable clinically non palpable breast mass

 

Ultrasound has no role in detecting non-palpable breast cancers.

 

Ultrasound is particularly useful in young women with dense breasts in whom mammograms are difficult to interpret, and in distinguishing cysts from solid lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Useful in young females with dense breast: Ultrasound is indeed beneficial in young women with dense breast tissue where mammograms can be harder to interpret due to the denseness of the tissue obscuring the view of potential abnormalities.

 

Option C. Differentiates between solid and Cystic lesions in the Breast: Ultrasound is particularly effective in distinguishing between solid and cystic lesions within the breast. This ability is crucial for determining the nature of a breast mass and guiding further diagnostic and treatment actions.

 

Option D. Guided biopsy can be done: Ultrasound-guided biopsy is a well-established procedure that uses ultrasound imaging to guide the needle to the precise location of the abnormal tissue in the breast for sampling. This is particularly useful for targeting lesions that are visible on ultrasound but not palpable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ultrasound should not be considered a standalone screening tool for non-palpable breast masses or those not detected by mammography. However, it is invaluable in specific scenarios such as evaluating women with dense breasts, distinguishing between cystic and solid breast lesions, and facilitating guided biopsies.

choices.text: Weight loss+ Metformin + induction of ovulation with urinary gonadotrophins
Weight loss + folic acid, Try for spontaneous induction, if failed move to induction of ovulation
Metformin + finasteride + Induction of ovulation
Weight loss+ Metformin + Induction of ovulation with clomiphene

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman, experiencing 6 years of infertility, possesses a BMI of 33 and exhibits facial hair. Further investigations have diagnosed her with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) and observed tubal spillage from both sides. Given her desire to conceive with her husband, what would be the most suitable management plan for her? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Weight loss + folic acid, try for spontaneous induction, if failed move to induction of ovulation

 

Notably, even a modest weight loss (approximately 5% of body weight) can be beneficial for restoring ovulatory cycles in some obese PCOS patients. Therefore, spontaneous induction is attempted as the first option. Additionally, folic acid is routinely administered as a preventive measure before conception to reduce the risk of neural tube defects.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Weight loss + Metformin + induction of ovulation with urinary gonadotrophins: While weight loss and Metformin are both appropriate treatments for PCOS, initiating ovulation induction with urinary gonadotrophins might be premature. Typically, less invasive methods such as Clomiphene or Letrozole are tried before using gonadotrophins.

 

Option C. Metformin + finasteride + Induction of ovulation: This option includes Metformin, which is beneficial for insulin resistance in PCOS, and finasteride, which is used for hirsutism but not typically for fertility management. Finasteride is not used to induce ovulation. This plan overlooks the initial approach of weight loss and the potential for spontaneous ovulation.

 

Option D. Weight loss + Metformin + Induction of ovulation with clomiphene: This option is partially correct. While weight loss and Metformin are appropriate, the recommendation to immediately use Clomiphene for induction without trying for spontaneous ovulation is not aligned with the step-wise approach in fertility management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a woman with PCOS and infertility, the initial management should include weight loss and folic acid supplementation, with attempts at spontaneous ovulation before progressing to more invasive induction methods.

questions.text:
Organize the given steps of Karyotyping into the accurate sequence. (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Collect cells by peripheral vein using a heparin syringe
  2. Culture in phytohaemoagglutinin
  3. Incubation at 37°C for 3 days
  4. Harvest with colchicine
  5. Routine staining with Giemsa
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3, 4, 5

 

Karyotyping is a process that allows for the visualization of chromosomes in a cell, usually to diagnose genetic diseases, identify chromosomal abnormalities, or analyze chromosomal structures. The accurate sequence for conducting karyotyping involves several key steps, each critical to ensuring accurate results.

 

  1. Collect cells by peripheral vein using a heparin syringe: Blood is typically drawn from a peripheral vein using a syringe containing heparin, an anticoagulant that prevents blood from clotting, thereby preserving the cells for further processing.
  2. Culture in phytohaemoagglutinin: The collected cells, which contain lymphocytes, are then cultured in a medium containing phytohaemoagglutinin (PHA), a mitogen that stimulates lymphocytes to enter mitosis. This step is crucial because chromosomes are most easily visualized and analyzed during mitosis.
  3. Incubation at 37°C for 3 days: The cell culture is incubated at 37 degrees Celsius for approximately 3 days to allow the cells to grow and divide, ensuring a sufficient number of cells reach the metaphase stage of mitosis.
  4. Harvest with colchicine: Colchicine is added to the culture to arrest cells in metaphase by disrupting the mitotic spindle formation. This ensures that a large number of cells are caught in metaphase, where chromosomes are most condensed and visible for karyotyping.
  5. Routine staining with Giemsa: After harvesting, the cells are fixed, dropped onto a slide, and stained with Giemsa stain. This stain provides a distinct banding pattern on the chromosomes, which helps in identifying and analyzing the structure and number of chromosomes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The accurate sequence for conducting Karyotyping is outlined below:

questions.text: Identify the given ECG? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Torsade’s de pointes

 

Torsade’s de pointes is characterized by a polymorphic ventricular tachycardia with varying QRS complex amplitudes and a twisting around the baseline.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Ventricular fibrillation: Characterized by a chaotic and irregular waveform without identifiable QRS complexes.
 

Option C. Atrial flutter: Shows a sawtooth pattern of atrial activity.
 

Option D. Monomorphic ventricular tachycardia: Shows uniform QRS complexes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Torsade’s de pointes are a type of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia with a characteristic twisting pattern.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presented with generalized fatigue, frequent urination, and increased thirst over the past few months. He mentions that he has also been experiencing muscle weakness and occasional abdominal discomfort. His abdomen spine X-ray shows the below finding. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hyperparathyroidism

 

The presented clinical scenario and X-ray reveal widespread calcification in both kidneys, indicating a condition known as nephrocalcinosis, often associated with hyperparathyroidism.

 

Nephrocalcinosis is characterized by the accumulation of calcium in the kidney parenchyma or tubules, and it commonly arises from conditions that lead to elevated calcium levels, such as hyperparathyroidism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wilson's disease: This is a genetic disorder that causes copper accumulation in tissues, leading to neurological and hepatic symptoms. It does not typically present with nephrocalcinosis or the specific set of symptoms described, such as muscle weakness and abdominal discomfort related to calcium imbalance.

 

Option B. Addison's disease: This condition involves adrenal insufficiency and can present with fatigue and abdominal pain but is not associated with nephrocalcinosis. It also does not explain the hypercalcemia indicated by kidney calcifications in the X-ray.

 

Option C. Cystic fibrosis: Primarily affects the lungs and digestive system, leading to thick mucus secretions and digestive complications. It is not associated with kidney calcifications or the hormonal imbalances of the parathyroid gland as seen in hyperparathyroidism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Widespread kidney calcifications seen on X-ray, coupled with symptoms of fatigue, frequent urination, and increased thirst, are suggestive of hyperparathyroidism. This condition results from excessive secretion of parathyroid hormone, leading to elevated blood calcium levels and subsequent calcium deposition in organs like the kidneys (nephrocalcinosis).

questions.text: Identify the following image: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ranula

 

The given clinical scenario and the image showing a cystic swelling on the floor of the mouth points to a diagnosis of a Ranula.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemangioma: A benign tumor made up of blood vessels, often appearing as a birthmark or red growth.

 

Option B. Cystic hygroma: A fluid-filled sac that results from a blockage in the lymphatic system, often present at birth. It presents as a posterior neck swelling.

 

Option C. Branchial cyst: A congenital epithelial cyst that arises from remnants of the branchial arches, usually presenting as a neck lump.

questions.text:
Which of the provided statements about the muscle depicted in the image are true? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

 

  1. They retract the scapula along with the middle fibers of Trapezius
  2. They elevate the scapula along with fibers of Trapezius
  3. They rotate the scapula tilting the glenoid cavity inferiorly
  4. They rotate the scapula tilting the glenoid cavity superiorly
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1, 2, 3

 

Explanation:

 

Marked muscle in the image given is Rhomboid Major and minor.

 

 

1. They retract the scapula along with the middle fibers of Trapezius:

 

  • True. Both the rhomboideus major and minor muscles play a role in scapular retraction. This means they help pull the scapula (shoulder blade) toward the midline of the body, which is an action involved in retracting the scapula. The middle fibers of the trapezius muscle also contribute to scapular retraction.
     

2. They elevate the scapula along with fibers of Trapezius:

 

  • True. The Rhomboids retract the scapula superiorly and medially from the medial border of the scapula, this in turn assists in elevation of the scapula along with upper fibers of trapezius..
     

3. They rotate the scapula tilting the glenoid cavity inferiorly:

 

  • True. When scapula is retracted and elevated along the medial border by rhomboids the glenoid cavity turns inferiorly (the socket of the shoulder joint).

     

Other Option:
 

4. They rotate the scapula tilting the glenoid cavity superiorly:

 

  • False. The primary action of the rhomboideus major and minor muscles is not to tilt the glenoid cavity superiorly. Their main functions involve scapular retraction and elevation, as discussed in statements 1 and 2. Tilted movement of the glenoid cavity superiorly is not a primary function associated with these muscles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Rhomboid Major and Minor muscles are key players in scapular stabilization, involved in retraction, elevation, and downward rotation of the scapula, aligning the glenoid cavity in a position that supports optimal shoulder function.

questions.text:
A patient presents with severe vomiting and diarrhea and has orthostatic hypotension. What metabolic abnormalities would you expect in this patient? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

1.Hypokalemia

2.Hypochloremia

3.Metabolic alkalosis

4.Respiratory alkalosis
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3

 

Severe vomiting and diarrhea can lead to multiple metabolic abnormalities: Hypokalemia, Hypochloremia, metabolic alkalosis with hyponatremia.

 

1. Hypokalemia: Loss of potassium through vomiting and diarrhea.

 

2. Hypochloremia: Loss of chloride.

 

3. Metabolic alkalosis: Loss of gastric acids.

 

These changes are due to the loss of electrolytes and fluids.

 

Other Option:

 

4. Respiratory alkalosis involves hyperventilation and a decrease in carbon dioxide, which is unrelated to the described condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Severe vomiting and diarrhea typically cause hypokalemia, hypochloremia, and metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text: Before conducting an A-V fistula procedure, which of the following tests is typically conducted? The image of the test is given below: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Allen's test

 

The given image represents Allen’s test, which indicates the patency of the radial and ulna artery in supplying the hand. Both arteries are compressed alternatively, to check if limb will survive in absence of radial artery (which will be now used in creation of AV fistula).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adson's test: Adson's test is a provocative test for Thoracic Outlet Syndrome accompanied by compression of the subclavian artery by a cervical rib or tightened anterior and middle scalene muscles. Patient is asked to turn his head to affected side and take a deep breath. Ipsilateral radial pulse will become weak in thoracic outlet syndrome.

 

 

Option C. Elevated arm stress test: Elevated arm stress test is a diagnostic tool used in the identification of Thoracic Outlet Syndrome. The patient is asked to abduct his shoulder and flex his forearm and open and close his fists. In presence of thoracic outlet syndrome, the affected limb will get cramps (ischemic) or paresthesia (neurogenic).

 

 

Option D. Nicoladoni's test: Nicoladoni's test is to be elicited in cases of AV fistula. There is slowing of heart rate in response to manual compression of fistula.

questions.text:
Organize the subsequent afferent columns in the floor of the fourth ventricle, proceeding from the medial to the lateral direction. (INICET MAY 2023)

 

1. General somatic

2. General visceral

3. Special somatic

4. Special visceral
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 2, 4, 1, 3

 

The question is regarding afferent columns hence we will only look at the afferent columns to arrange these options and not the whole arrangement of all the columns in the diagram.

 

The afferent columns in the floor of the fourth ventricle can be categorized from medial to lateral into four types: general visceral, special visceral, general somatic, and special somatic.

 

 

 

The subsequent afferent columns in the floor of the fourth ventricle can be organized from medial to lateral as follows:

 

2. General visceral: The general visceral column carries sensory information from the internal organs, such as the visceral sensations of hunger, fullness, and discomfort.

 

4. Special visceral: This column includes sensory input related to the special senses of taste and hearing. The special visceral sensory column carries information from the taste buds and the cochlea (auditory part of the ear).

 

1. General somatic: The general somatic column carries sensory information related to touch, temperature, pain, and pressure from the body's skin and musculoskeletal system.

 

3. Special somatic: This column contains sensory input related to the special senses of vision, equilibrium, and proprioception (awareness of body position). It includes input from the eyes, ears (for balance), and proprioceptors in muscles and joints.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the floor of the fourth ventricle, the arrangement of the afferent sensory columns from medial to lateral is - 2. General visceral, 4. Special visceral, 1. General somatic & 3. Special somatic

questions.text: Which of the following is a new approved drug for Rett syndrome. (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Trofinetide

 

Rett syndrome is an X-linked genetic disorder mostly seen in females. Symptoms include impairments in language and coordination, and repetitive movements. It occurs due to mutation in MECP2 gene.

 

Trofinetide is an analog of glypromate or glycine–proline–glutamate (GPE), a naturally occurring protein in the brain and the N-terminal tripeptide of insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1). GPE exhibits neuroprotective properties: it protects neurons from glutamate-mediated excitotoxicity and oxidative stress.

 

Trofinetide has similar neuroprotective properties and has longer half-life.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Zavegepant: This is a CGRP antagonist approved for the treatment of migraine, not for Rett syndrome.

 

Option C. Sparsentan: This is a dual endothelin antagonist and angiotensin receptor antagonist approved for the treatment of IgA nephropathy, not Rett syndrome.

 

Option D. Elacestrant: This is a selective estrogen receptor downregulator approved as an oral treatment for breast cancer, not Rett syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trofinetide is a newly approved drug for Rett syndrome, exhibiting neuroprotective properties similar to those of glypromate (GPE), and is beneficial for treating the symptoms of this genetic disorder.

questions.text: In a case of fatality resulting from firearm injuries, the entrance wound displays solely an abrasion collar. The firearm's firing distance probably is? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Distant range

 

An abrasion collar is a ring of abraded skin around the entrance wound of a bullet. It is caused by the bullet's friction as it penetrates the skin. This feature can be found at any distance, including distant range. However, additional features such as singeing, blackening, and tattooing are present only at closer ranges. Since the question states that the entrance wound displays solely an abrasion collar, it indicates that none of the other close-range features are present, suggesting a distant range.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Contact range: At contact range, there would be singeing, blackening, and tattooing right at the margins of the wound, as well as potential muzzle imprint and burning due to the close proximity of the firearm.

 

Option B. Close range: At close range, there would be significant blackening and tattooing around the wound, indicating the firearm was discharged from a short distance but not in contact with the skin.

 

Option C. Near range: At near range, there would still be some blackening and tattooing around the wound, but these features diminish with increasing distance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

There are five features of firearm entry wound (inner most to outermost):

 

  • Grease Collar (inner most)
  • Abrasion collar
  • Singeing
  • Blackening
  • Tattooing (outer most)

 

Out of these five features, Abrasion collar and Grease collar can be found in any entry wound, irrespective of the distance between victim and firearm. This is because these are produced by bullet itself as it enters the body.

 

Whereas Singeing, Blackening and Tattooing occur only upto a limited distance

questions.text:
A female with nephrotic syndrome underwent a renal biopsy. Which of the following statements is correct? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. FSGS cannot be diagnosed by a percutaneous renal biopsy
  2. Patient should be observed for 24 hours following biopsy
  3. Dark red clots in the urine following a biopsy indicate a hematoma
  4. Patients with features of systemic amyloidosis and renal involvement can undergo abdominal fat pad biopsy instead of renal biopsy
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2,3,4

 

Following a renal biopsy, it is crucial to monitor the patient for potential complications, including bleeding and hematoma formation.

 

2. Observation post-biopsy: Patients should be observed for 24 hours following a renal biopsy to monitor for complications such as bleeding or infection.

 

3. Dark red clots in urine: Dark red clots in the urine following a biopsy can indicate a hematoma. This is a potential complication that needs to be monitored.

 

4. Abdominal fat pad biopsy: Patients with systemic amyloidosis and renal involvement can undergo an abdominal fat pad biopsy as an alternative to a renal biopsy. This method can help diagnose systemic amyloidosis with less risk compared to a renal biopsy.

 

Other Option:

 

1. FSGS cannot be diagnosed by a percutaneous renal biopsy: This statement is incorrect. Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) can indeed be diagnosed by a percutaneous renal biopsy. The biopsy helps in identifying the characteristic histological changes associated with FSGS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Post-biopsy observation, recognition of biopsy-related complications, and alternative biopsy methods for systemic amyloidosis are essential in nephrotic syndrome management.

questions.text: Which of the following vessels is involved in the condition affecting the region marked in red in the image shown below?(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery

 

Explanation:

 

Lateral medullary syndrome, also known as Wallenberg syndrome or posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) syndrome, is a neurological condition caused by a blockage or disruption of blood flow in the PICA, a major artery that supplies the medulla. It results from damage to multiple structures in the medulla, including the nuclei of cranial nerves (such as the nucleus ambiguus), the spinothalamic tract, and the descending sympathetic pathways.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior Cerebellar Artery: The superior cerebellar artery primarily supplies the superior surface of the cerebellum. Blockage or injury to this artery can lead to symptoms related to dysfunction of the upper cerebellum but is not associated with the classic features of lateral medullary syndrome.

 

Option C. Posterior Superior Cerebellar Artery: The posterior superior cerebellar artery supplies the superior part of the cerebellum and the superior cerebellar peduncle. It is not directly associated with the lateral medullary syndrome. Blockage of this artery can lead to symptoms related to the superior cerebellum but not the specific features seen in lateral medullary syndrome.

 

Option D. Cerebral Artery: The term "cerebral artery" is a broad term that refers to arteries supplying the brain, including the anterior, middle, and posterior cerebral arteries. Blockage or issues with these arteries can cause various types of strokes or neurological symptoms, but they are not directly related to lateral medullary syndrome, which specifically involves the medulla and the PICA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery (PICA) is a major artery that supplies the lateral and posterior parts of the medulla, as well as the inferior surface of the cerebellum. When there is an issue with the PICA, such as a clot or blockage, it can affect the blood supply to the lateral medulla. This leads to the classic symptoms of lateral medullary syndrome, including dysphagia (difficulty swallowing), hoarseness, vertigo, nystagmus (involuntary eye movements), ataxia (loss of coordination), and various sensory disturbances.

 

Lateral medullary syndrome, also known as Wallenberg syndrome, typically results from a blockage or disruption of blood flow in the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA).

questions.text: A baby is brought to OPD for 10-week DPT vaccination appointment. He previously experienced a fever exceeding 40°C and had an inconsolable cry at 6 weeks old after receiving a vaccination. What would be the recommended course of action moving forward? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Give DT vaccine

 

The child experienced a hypotonic-hyporesponsive episode or severe reaction (fever >40°C and persistent inconsolable crying) after the previous DPT dose. These are precautionary (not absolute contraindications) for pertussis-containing vaccines like DPT, but they warrant switching to a less reactogenic formulation.

 

DT (Diphtheria + Tetanus) vaccine is recommended in such cases, as it omits the pertussis component, which is most often responsible for such adverse events.

 

This allows continuation of diphtheria and tetanus protection while avoiding further adverse events from the pertussis component.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Avoid DPT vaccination: Incorrect. DPT is contraindicated, but not all vaccinations should be avoided. The child should still receive protection against diphtheria and tetanus.

 

Option C. Give DPT vaccine: Incorrect. Given the prior adverse reaction, repeating DPT may risk more serious reactions. It’s prudent to avoid the pertussis component.

 

Option D. Defer by 4 weeks: Incorrect. There's no benefit in deferring the dose. The issue is not timing but the component that caused the reaction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Severe reactions (such as high fever >40.5°C, persistent inconsolable crying >3 hours, or hypotonic-hyporesponsive episodes) after a previous DPT dose are indications to withhold the pertussis component in future doses. The child should receive the DT vaccine instead.

questions.text: Where is the SRY region located?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Short arm of Y chromosome

 

Explanation

 

  • The SRY gene is located on the short arm (p-arm) of the Y chromosome (Yp11). This gene is often referred to as the "master switch" for male development. It codes for a transcription factor that triggers the development of testes in an embryo, which, in turn, leads to the development of male reproductive structures.

 

  • It is an intron less sex-determining gene on the Y chromosome.

 

 

 

Y- chromosome 

 

The SRY (Sex-determining Region Y) gene is a critical genetic region responsible for initiating male sex determination and the development of male reproductive organs in mammals, including humans. Let's discuss the location of the SRY region in detail for each option:

 

Other Options:

 

Option B) Short arm of X chromosome: Incorrect. The SRY gene is not located on the X chromosome. It is specific to the Y chromosome and plays a pivotal role in male sex determination.

 

Option C) Long arm of Y chromosome: Incorrect. The SRY gene is not on the long arm (q-arm) of the Y chromosome. It is situated on the short arm, as mentioned earlier.

 

Option D) Long arm of X chromosome: Incorrect. The SRY gene is not present on the X chromosome. It is unique to the Y chromosome and is responsible for the differentiation of the bipotential gonad into the testis during early embryonic development.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sex- determining region Y protein (SRY) gene or TDF ( Testis-determining factor ) is a DNA binding protein encoded by the SRY gene that is responsible for the initiation of male sex determination in mammals. Its expression causes the development of primary sex cords, which later develop into seminiferous tubules.

questions.text: A patient recovered from hepatitis B infection. Which of the following curve represents antibodies seen 4 weeks post-recovery? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anti HBs

 

After recovery from hepatitis B infection, the patient will have antibodies against the hepatitis B surface antigen (anti-HBS), indicating immunity. The key points related to hepatitis B infection and recovery include:

 

HBsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen): Initially present during the acute phase of infection, indicating active infection. It will eventually drop and become negative upon recovery.

 

Anti-HBc (Hepatitis B core antibody): Initially, anti-HBc IgM is positive during the acute phase, which then transitions to anti-HBc IgG as the infection progresses. The total anti-HBc represents both IgM initially and IgG later on.

 

HBeAg (Hepatitis B e antigen): Indicates active viral replication and high infectivity. It decreases as the virus is cleared.

 

Anti-HBs (Hepatitis B surface antibody): The protective antibody indicating recovery and immunity from hepatitis B infection. This antibody appears after the disappearance of HBsAg and is a marker of immunity post-recovery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anti HBc: Anti-HBc indicates past or current infection with hepatitis B. Initially, IgM anti-HBc is present during the acute infection, and later, IgG anti-HBc persists. However, it does not specifically indicate recovery and immunity.


Option C. HBeAg: HBeAg is a marker of active viral replication and high infectivity. It is present during the active infection phase and decreases as the infection resolves.


Option D. HBsAg: HBsAg indicates active hepatitis B infection. It is present during the acute phase of infection and disappears upon recovery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-HBs antibodies indicate recovery and immunity from hepatitis B infection. This is the only protective antibody that signifies the patient has successfully recovered from the infection and has developed immunity.

questions.text: In this case, a young boy is exhibiting symptoms of reduced mood, decreased energy, and diminished engagement with his environment. He has refrained from eating for the past week and his thoughts include phrases like "I have lost my mind. I am deceased. How can I consume food?". What is the specific delusion in this scenario? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nihilistic delusion

 

Nihilistic delusion (delusion of negation, Cotard syndrome): Patients may deny the existence of their body, their mind, or the world in general. For example, a patient with severe depression claimed that all his internal organs have rotted.

 

Here, the best answer is Nihilistic delusion rather than Cotard syndrome because the question has specifically asked the type of delusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypochondriacal delusion: Hypochondriacal delusion is an illness anxiety disorder. It is characterized by a preoccupation with having or acquiring a serious physical illness. The preoccupation persists despite normal investigations and medical reassurances.

 

Option D. Bizarre delusion: Scientifically impossible and culturally implausible (un-understandable). For example, a patient claimed that aliens stole his heart and lungs, and now he is living without those organs.

choices.text: He has consumed alcohol and is under the influence of alcohol
He has consumed alcohol but is not under its influence

questions.text: In an examination for drunkenness, a person smells of alcohol and his conjunctiva appear red. During his motor examination, it is observed that he can walk in a straight line and can talk normally. Which of the following statements is true?(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. He has consumed alcohol but is not under its influence

 

The presented situation depicts an individual emitting the scent of alcohol, yet their motor coordination remains unaffected, and there is no slurring of speech. This suggests that they might have consumed alcohol previously, but they are not currently under its influence.

 

If the individual were unable to walk in a straight line or displayed slurred speech, they would be considered under the influence of alcohol.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. He has consumed alcohol: This statement is true, but it does not address the influence of alcohol on the person's abilities.

 

Option B. He has consumed alcohol and is under the influence of alcohol: This statement would be true if there were signs of impaired motor coordination or slurred speech, which are not present in this case.

 

Option D. He has not consumed alcohol: This statement is false as the smell of alcohol and red conjunctiva indicate consumption of alcohol.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blood-Alcohol Concentration and Symptoms:

choices.text: The assertion is independently a true statement, but the reasons is independently a false statement.
The assertion is independently a false statement, but the reasons is independently a true statement.
Both assertion and reason are independently true and the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion
Both assertion and reason are independently true and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion

questions.text:
Assertion: Resting membrane potential is dependent on proteins and phosphate ions.

 

Reason: Diffusion potential can be calculated using Nernst Equation. (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both assertion and reason are independently true and the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion

 

Resting membrane potential refers to the electrical charge difference across the cell membrane of a neuron or other excitable cells when the cell is at rest, meaning it is not actively transmitting signals. This potential is maintained by the uneven distribution of ions, primarily sodium (Na+), potassium (K+), chloride (Cl-), and other negative ions, across the cell membrane.

 

Nernst equation is used to calculate the diffusion potential (also known as the equilibrium potential) for a specific ion across a semi-permeable membrane.

 

 

Where:

 

  • E is the equilibrium potential for the ion.
  • R is the ideal gas constant.
  • T is the absolute temperature (in Kelvin).
  • z is the valence (charge) of the ion.
  • F is Faraday's constant.
  • [Cout]​ and [Cin]​ are the concentrations of the ion outside and inside the membrane, respectively.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Resting membrane potential is maintained by the uneven distribution of ions, primarily sodium (Na+), potassium (K+), chloride (Cl-), and other negative ions (including proteins and phosphate ions), across the cell membrane.
  • The Nernst equation is used to calculate the diffusion potential (also known as the equilibrium potential) for a specific ion across a semi-permeable membrane.

questions.text: Identify the following image. (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Blister due to antemortem burns

 

The antemortem blister presents itself as an elevated dome, containing serous fluid enriched with proteins and chlorides. The surrounding base exhibits reddening and swollen papillae. In the case of antemortem burns, the adjacent skin displays heightened enzyme activity, particularly for sulfhydryl groups in all skin layers. This reaction is accompanied by increased levels of ATP, esterase’s, aminopeptidases, acid, and alkaline phosphatase. These vital reactions indicate notable cellular exudation and reactive tissue changes, which are distinctive features of antemortem burns.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blister due to barbiturate poisoning: Barbiturate poisoning typically causes CNS depression, respiratory issues, and cardiovascular problems, not specific blister formation like burns.

 

Option C. Edema due to chemical burn: Chemical burns might cause edema, but the specific blister shown in the image is more characteristic of thermal burns.

 

Option D. Pemphigus vulgaris: Pemphigus vulgaris presents with flaccid blisters and erosions rather than the tense blister shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antemortem burn blisters are characterized by elevated domes filled with serous fluid, reddened surrounding base, and high enzyme activity, indicating significant cellular and tissue reactions distinct from other types of blisters or burns.

questions.text:
BRCA 1 gene is associated with______:

 

  1. Repair of ds DNA break
  2. Risk of development of ovarian cancer
  3. Tumor suppressor gene
  4. Mutation is seen in the subset of Fanconi anemia
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3

 

The statements associated with the BRCA1 gene are:

 

  • Repair of double-stranded (ds) DNA breaks: BRCA1 plays a critical role in the repair process of ds DNA breaks through homologous recombination.
  • Risk of development of ovarian cancer: Women with mutations in the BRCA1 gene have a higher risk of developing ovarian cancer, in addition to breast cancer.
  • Tumor suppressor gene: BRCA1 is classified as a tumor suppressor gene, meaning it helps to prevent uncontrolled cell division and tumor growth by repairing DNA damage.

 

Both BRCA1 and BRCA2 are tumor suppressor genes that protect against certain cancers. Mutations in these genes increase the risk of breast and ovarian cancers, especially in women. They also play an essential role in the repair of DNA damage through homologous recombination, which fixes double-strand DNA breaks.

 

Mutations in BRCA1 do not commonly cause Fanconi anemia, although mutations in BRCA2 are more commonly linked to a subset of Fanconi anemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 1,3,4: While BRCA1 is associated with DNA repair and is a tumor suppressor gene, it is not commonly linked to Fanconi anemia, which is more associated with BRCA2 mutations.

 

Option C. 2,3,4: Although the BRCA1 mutation increases the risk of ovarian cancer and functions as a tumor suppressor, its connection to Fanconi anemia is more relevant to BRCA2 mutations, not BRCA1.

 

Option D. 1,2,4: While BRCA1 plays a role in DNA repair and is linked to ovarian cancer risk, it is not associated with Fanconi anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

BRCA1 is a tumor suppressor gene primarily associated with the repair of double-stranded DNA breaks, the development of breast and ovarian cancer, and it functions to suppress tumor formation. BRCA2 mutations are more commonly linked to Fanconi anemia.

choices.text: Increase in intrathoracic pressure adding to left ventricular pressure
Increase in intrathoracic pressure adding to aortic pressure

questions.text: The rise in blood pressure that occurs at the onset of the Valsalva maneuver is a result of? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increase in intrathoracic pressure adding to aortic pressure

 

Valsalva maneuver can lead to a temporary increase in blood pressure due to its effects on the cardiovascular system. This phenomenon can be explained by:

 

  • Increased Intrathoracic Pressure: By trying to exhale against a closed airway, you create increased pressure within your chest cavity. This can compress the large blood vessels.
  • Increased Sympathetic Activity: The increased intrathoracic pressure triggers the body’s sympathetic nervous system, which is responsible for the “fight or flight” response. This leads to the release of stress hormones like adrenaline and norepinephrine. These hormones cause blood vessels to constrict (vasoconstriction), which further raises blood pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase in intrathoracic pressure adding to left ventricular pressure: Incorrect. The pressure increase primarily affects the aorta and systemic circulation, not just the left ventricular pressure.

 

Option C. Increase in left atrial pressure: Incorrect. While there may be a slight increase in left atrial pressure, it is not the primary cause of the rise in blood pressure observed during the Valsalva maneuver.

 

Option D. Increase in left ventricular volume: Incorrect. The maneuver does not directly increase left ventricular volume; instead, it increases pressure within the thoracic cavity affecting the aorta.

 

Educational Objective:

The rise in blood pressure at the onset of the Valsalva maneuver is primarily due to the increase in intrathoracic pressure adding to aortic pressure, along with increased sympathetic activity.

questions.text: Which among the following indicates severe COVID-19 ? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) SpO2 < 85% on room air


Severe COVID-19 is characterized by a significant drop in oxygen saturation. An SpO2 of less than 85% on room air indicates severe hypoxemia.

 

Any SpO2 of less than 90% indicate severe COVID and 90-93% indicates moderate COVID

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. RR >24/min: Indicates moderate, not severe, COVID-19. RR>30/min indicate severe COVID
 

Option B. MAP 70 mmHg: Does not specifically indicate severe COVID-19. Hemodynamic instability i.e. MAP <65 OR 65 or above with vasopressors indicates severe COVID. 
 

Option C. Lung infiltrates >42% on CT: Not a specific criterion for COVID-19 severity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Severe COVID-19 is indicated by an SpO2 of less than 85% on room air.

questions.text: Identify the mode of inheritance from the pedigree chart given below: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Autosomal dominant

 

The pedigree chart given is suggestive of an autosomal dominant Disorders

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Autosomal dominant inheritance is characterized by a consistent appearance of affected individuals in every generation, with no sex bias and manifestation in individuals who carry one copy of the mutant allele.

questions.text: A woman who is using oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) experiences white vaginal discharge without itching or a foul odor. The discharge causes yellow staining on her underwear. Upon examination, the discharge reveals the presence of typical lactobacilli and an acidic pH. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increased normal vaginal discharge

 

The given clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of Leucorrhea (Increased vaginal discharge). Leucorrhea presents with excessive whitish, yellowish, or greenish vaginal discharge. It is non-irritant, no purulent and non-offensive.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vaginal candidiasis: Vaginal candidiasis presents with itching and a white thick, curdy discharge.

 

Option C. Bacterial vaginosis: Bacterial vaginosis is characterized by a thin, gray, foul-smelling discharge.

 

Option D. Chlamydia infection: Chlamydia infection can by asymptomatic or present with discharge but is not associated with yellow discharge.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Increased normal vaginal discharge, known as leucorrhea, can occur in women using oral contraceptive pills. This discharge is typically white or yellow, non-irritant, no purulent, no offensive, and associated with the presence of lactobacilli and an acidic pH.

questions.text: Following a hysterectomy, the patient received morphine for pain management both during the post-operative period and while in the ward. The current symptoms include respiratory depression and constricted (pinpoint) pupils. What would be the recommended medication for this patient? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Naloxone

 

  • The given clinical scenario is suggestive of opioid poisoning due to morphine, for which IV Naloxone can be administered.
  • In Morphine poisoning, the patient usually present in comatose state with low BP and heart rate as μ-receptor causes depression of brain including cardiovascular center.

 

SYMPTOMS OF OPIOID POISONING

 

  • Coma, respiratory depression, pinpoint pupils
  • Hypotension, bradycardia
  • Bradypnea
  • Hypothermia

 

ANTAGONISTS

 

  • Naloxone - Short acting, given iv
  • Naltrexone - Long acting, given Orally
  • DOC for acute opioid poisoning → Naloxone
  • DOC for maintenance in opioid poisoning → Naltrexone
    • Naloxone is added to oral opioids to reduce addictive potential.
    • Naltrexone is used to decrease craving in alcoholics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pethidine/Meperidine is a μ receptor agonist.

 

Option B. Atropine is an anticholinergic drug. Used in cases of organophosphate poisoning.

 

Option D. Buprenorphine is a partial μ receptor agonist and an antagonist at delta and kappa receptor. It has ceiling Effect on respiratory depression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Naloxone is the drug of choice for treating acute opioid overdose, characterized by symptoms such as respiratory depression, pinpoint pupils, and coma. It acts rapidly to reverse the effects of opioids by competitively inhibiting their action at opioid receptors.

choices.text: Sickle cell anemia

questions.text: Which of the following disorders is caused due to abnormal folding of proteins? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease

 

Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease is caused due to abnormal folding of proteins.

 

CREUTZFELDT-JAKOB DISEASE (CJD)

 

  • Rare, degenerative, and fatal brain disorder.
  • Belongs to the group of transmissible spongiform encephalopathies (TSEs).
  • Results in the rapid deterioration of neurological function.

 

Causes

 

  • Abnormal prion proteins (misfolded) accumulate in the brain, leading to nerve cell damage.
  • Can be sporadic, genetic, or acquired through contaminated medical procedures

 

Symptoms

 

  • Rapidly progressive dementia.
  • Muscle stiffness, twitching, and weakness.
  • Behavioral changes, mood swings, and hallucinations.
  • Difficulty walking, speaking, and swallowing

 

Diagnosis

 

  • Based on clinical symptoms, medical history, and neurological examination.
  • Brain imaging and cerebrospinal fluid analysis to rule out other conditions.

 

Treatment

 

  • No cure or specific treatment available.
  • Supportive care to manage symptoms and maintain quality of life.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cirrhosis: Primarily caused by chronic liver injury due to alcohol abuse, hepatitis, or other liver diseases, and is not related to abnormal protein folding.

 

Option C. Nephritic syndrome: Characterized by inflammation of the glomeruli, leading to hematuria, hypertension, and proteinuria. The condition is generally caused by immune-mediated mechanisms, not by abnormal protein folding.

 

Option D. Sickle cell anemia: While it is caused by a protein mutation, it is not related to the abnormal folding of proteins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease is a disorder caused by the abnormal folding of prion proteins, leading to severe and fatal brain degeneration.

choices.text: Increase in IL-2, IL-4 and IL-5

questions.text: Mechanism of thalidomide teratogenicity include all except
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Increase in IL-2, IL-4 and IL-5

 

Thalidomide actually suppresses the production of certain cytokines, including IL-2, IL-4, and IL-5. The suppression of these interleukins is part of its immunomodulatory effects, not a mechanism of teratogenicity. Thalidomide suppresses the production of interleukins which is an important mechanism in treatment of multiple myeloma.

 

The exact mechanism of thalidomide's teratogenicity is not completely understood, but several mechanisms have been proposed:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inhibition of angiogenesis: Thalidomide has been found to inhibit angiogenesis, which is the formation of new blood vessels. This inhibition can disrupt the development of the fetus, leading to birth defects. This mechanism is widely accepted as a significant contributor to the teratogenic effects of thalidomide.

 

Option C. Generation of oxygen free radicals: Thalidomide may cause oxidative stress by generating oxygen free radicals, which can damage developing cells. This oxidative stress can contribute to teratogenic effects.

 

Option D. Binding to cereblon: Recent studies have shown that thalidomide binds to a protein called cereblon, which is involved in limb outgrowth and ear development. When thalidomide binds to cereblon, it disrupts the normal function of this protein, leading to the birth defects associated with thalidomide use.

 

Other mechanism includes -

 

  • Interference with cellular signalling: Thalidomide may interfere with various cellular signalling pathways, such as those involving fibroblast growth factors, which are important for embryonic development.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thalidomide's teratogenicity is primarily associated with mechanisms such as the inhibition of angiogenesis, generation of oxygen free radicals, and binding to the cereblon protein. It does not cause an increase in IL-2, IL-4, and IL-5; in fact, it suppresses these interleukins.

questions.text: Xanthurenic Acid in urine indicates: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin B6 deficiency

 

Xanthurenic assay a.k.a. Tryptophan load test. Xanthurenic acid in urine indicates Vitamin B6 deficiency. Xanthurenic acid is a metabolite that is formed during the breakdown of the amino acid tryptophan. Under normal conditions, tryptophan is metabolized along the kynurenine pathway, which involves the conversion of tryptophan to various intermediate compounds. One of these intermediates is xanthurenic acid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin B1 deficiency: Measurement of erythrocyte transketolase activity, thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP) effect, and blood thiamine levels.

 

Option C. Niacin deficiency: Measurement of urinary N-methylnicotinamide (NMN) excretion, and niacin load test.

 

Option D. Vitamin B2 deficiency: Measurement of erythrocyte glutathione reductase activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In individuals with a deficiency of vitamin B6 (pyridoxine), the conversion of tryptophan to niacin (vitamin B3) is impaired. As a result, tryptophan is metabolized through an alternative pathway, leading to the accumulation of xanthurenic acid. Therefore, the presence of xanthurenic acid in urine is indicative of a vitamin B6 deficiency.

questions.text: In Pompe’s disease, enzyme deficiency is? (INICET May 2023
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lysosomal acid alpha glucosidase

 

Pompe's disease, also known as glycogen storage disease type II or acid maltase deficiency, is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the deficiency or absence of the enzyme lysosomal acid alpha glucosidase (also called acid alpha-glucosidase or acid maltase). This enzyme is responsible for breaking down glycogen, a complex sugar molecule, into glucose within the lysosomes of cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Phosphofructokinase: Phosphofructokinase is an enzyme involved in the regulation of glycolysis, the metabolic pathway that breaks down glucose to produce energy in the form of ATP.

 

Option C. Muscle glycogen phosphorylase: Muscle glycogen phosphorylase is an enzyme responsible for the breakdown of glycogen in muscle tissue. Its deficiency causes McArdle’s disease.
