Option D. Lactate dehydrogenase: Lactate dehydrogenase is an enzyme involved in the conversion of lactate, a byproduct of anaerobic metabolism, back into pyruvate, which can enter the citric acid cycle for further energy production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In individuals with Pompe's disease, the deficiency of lysosomal acid alpha glucosidase leads to the accumulation of glycogen in various tissues, particularly the muscles. This glycogen buildup affects the proper functioning of cells and tissues, causing a wide range of symptoms, primarily affecting the muscles and respiratory system.

questions.text: An individual with type 2 diabetes mellitus was prescribed a medication that lowered their HbA1C levels from 7.6 to 6.7. Subsequently, the person began experiencing discomfort characterized by itching in the vulvovaginal region. What is the probable medication that was initiated for this individual? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Canagliflozin

 

The patient complaining of itching in genital region after consuming a drug to lower down HbA1C levels is likely pointing to urogenital infection, which is a side effect associated with Canagliflozin (SGLT2 inhibitor).

 

SGLT-2 INHIBITORS

 

  • Glucose is freely filtered by glomerulus but the clearance of glucose in urine is negligible.
  • Because the reabsorption takes place in proximal tubule by sodium glucose transporter (SGLT-2)
  • SGLT-2 inhibitors stop the reabsorption of glucose in PT resulting in glucosuria.
  • Most common side effect of SGLT-2 Inhibitors is Urinary Tract infections (urosepsis) and genital Tract infections. (e.g., Fournier’s gangrene)
  • If gliflozins are taken by type 1 diabetes patients, it controls blood sugar level and makes it normal and then if the patients stop taking insulin, it will result in Ketoacidosis (as type 1 diabetes is characterized by complete deficiency of insulin)
  • SLGT-2 inhibitors provide cardiovascular benefits. These are approved for treatment of CHF.
  • Drugs are.
    • Canagliflozin
    • Dapagliflozin
    • Empagliflozin
    • Ertugliflozin

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acarbose: This is an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor that primarily acts in the intestine to slow down the breakdown of complex carbohydrates. It is not usually associated with vulvovaginal itching.

 

Option C. Linagliptin: A DPP-4 inhibitor, Linagliptin is not typically associated with vulvovaginal itching or infections.

 

Option D. Liraglutide: This GLP-1 agonist is more commonly associated with gastrointestinal side effects rather than vulvovaginal itching.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Canagliflozin is an SGLT2 inhibitor that lowers blood sugar by causing more glucose to be excreted in the urine. It is known for causing genitourinary infections, including vulvovaginal candidiasis, which can result in symptoms like itching and discomfort.

questions.text:
An 18-month-old child with a 3-day history of watery diarrhea and vomiting presented with altered sensorium. Which of the following are differential diagnoses:

 

 

  1. Severe dehydration
  2. HUS
  3. Cerebral Venous Thrombosis
  4. Hyponatremia
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 3, 4

 

The differential diagnoses in a child with a history of watery diarrhea and altered sensorium include severe dehydration, cerebral venous thrombosis, and hyponatremia.

 

The lack of dysentery (bloody diarrhea) and the short period of interval between diarrheal episodes and the symptom complex help to rule out Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS). HUS is a form of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia usually occurring in children less than 5 years of age. HUS typically involves bloody diarrhea, hemolytic anemia, and kidney injury, which this child does not exhibit.

 

Other Options:

 

  • HUS (Option 2) is excluded due to the absence of bloody diarrhea and hemolytic anemia, which are typical features.
  • Severe dehydration (Option 1) is likely due to vomiting and diarrhea, leading to altered sensorium.
  • Cerebral venous thrombosis (Option 3) is a possible complication in severely dehydrated patients, leading to altered consciousness.
  • Hyponatremia (Option 4) can also be a consequence of prolonged diarrhea and vomiting, causing electrolyte imbalances and leading to neurological symptoms such as altered sensorium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The differential diagnoses of watery diarrhea and altered sensorium in a child include severe dehydration, cerebral venous thrombosis, and hyponatremia, while HUS is usually associated with bloody diarrhea and is ruled out in this case.

questions.text: Among the options provided, which protozoan parasite is found within Kupffer cells? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Leishmania donovani

 

  • Kupffer cells are macrophages of Liver.
  • Amastigote form of Leishmania donovani is engulfed by macrophages monocytes, and other reticuloendothelial cells → LD-body
  • LD bodies seen in peripheral smear of a patient with Kala azar

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Toxoplasma: In the human host, the parasites form tissue cysts, most commonly in skeletal muscle, myocardium, brain, and eyes

 

Option C. Babesia’s life cycle doesn’t involve liver. Sporozoites directly enter RBCs.

 

Option D. Plasmodium vivax: In the pre-erythrocytic stage, plasmodium sporozoites invade hepatocytes, where they undergo development into merozoites. Subsequently, these merozoites infiltrate red blood cells (RBCs).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The amastigote form of Leishmania donovani, also known as LD bodies, is found within macrophages, including Kupffer cells in the liver, during infection.

questions.text: A patient came to the emergency department with a history of being involved in a road traffic accident, resulting in a fracture of the femur shaft. The patient's condition was promptly stabilized. However, after a period of 12 hours, the individual experienced a sudden onset of difficulty breathing, confusion, and the appearance of small reddish-purple skin rashes (petechiae) over the chest and underarm areas. What potential diagnosis could explain these symptoms? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Fat embolism

 

  • The probable diagnosis derived from the given clinical scenario can be fat embolism.
  • Fat embolism although should be diagnosed with trauma to long bone, usually Femur and clinical presentation of pulmonary involvement, CNS depression and skin involvement (Petechiae).

 

FAT EMBOLISM SYNDROME

 

  • Fat embolism refers to the presence of fat globules in vital organs and peripheral circulation after fracture of a long bone or other major trauma.
  • Fat embolism syndrome reflects a serious systemic manifestation as a consequence to these emboli.
  • Fat embolism is more commonly seen in patients with multiple fractures and in fractures involving lower limbs especially femur.
  • Fat originates from the site of trauma, particularly from the injured marrow. Fat globules > 10 mm are considered significant.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Early warning signs are a slight rise in temperature and pulse rate (tachycardia).
    • The classical triad of fat embolism syndrome is:
      1. Respiratory symptoms: Dyspnea or tachypnea
      2. Neurological symptoms: Confusion or disorientation
      3. Petechial rash: In axilla, neck, periumbilical area, conjunctiva of lower lid, front and back of chest, shoulder
  • Diagnostic Criterion for Fat Embolism:

 

 

  • 1 major + 4 minor = Fat embolism

 

  • Prevention:
    • Fracture stabilization
    • Removing fat emboli from circulation by:
      • Lipolytic agents as heparin (increase serum lipase activity)
      • Hypertonic glucose (decrease FFA production)
  • Offset its effect by:
    • Dextran (expand plasma volume, reduces RBC aggregation and platelet adherence)
    • Aprotinin (protease inhibitor) – decreases platelet aggregation and serotonin release
    • Alcohol has vasodilator and lipolytic effect.
  • Treatment:
    • The aim of treatment is maintaining adequate oxygen level in the blood. If necessary, by using intermittent positive pressure ventilation. Oxygen is the only therapeutic tool of proven use.
    • It should be administered in sufficient amount to maintain arterial PO2 > 80 mm Hg. O2 toxicity (pneumonitis) is avoided by using O2 conc. below 40%.
    • Steroids are given to Avoid Pneumonitis

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Head injury. Based on the mechanism, head trauma is classified as blunt (the most common mechanism), penetrating (most fatal), and blast. Most severe TBIs result from motor vehicle collisions and falls. A good history concerning the mechanism of injury is important. GCS is used to describe the level of consciousness. A patient with mild head injury may present with swelling from a bump or a bruise, small, superficial cut in the scalp, headache, sensitivity to noise and light, irritability, confusion, dizziness, balance problems, nausea, problems with memory and/or concentration, blurred vision, tinnitus. Moderate to severe head injury symptoms may include any of the above plus loss of consciousness, severe headache that does not go away, repeated nausea and vomiting, loss of short-term memory, such as difficulty remembering the events that led right up to and through the traumatic event, slurred speech, difficulty with walking, weakness in one side or area of the body, sweating, pale skin, seizures, blood or clear fluid draining from the ears or nose, one pupil  is dilated, or looks larger, than the other eye and doesn't constrict, or get smaller, when exposed to light , deep cut or laceration in the scalp, open wound in the head, foreign object penetrating the head, coma.

 

Option C. Blunt trauma to chest. Chest trauma remains a serious problem in high-speed vehicle accidents. Thoracic trauma occurs in approximately 60% patients and has a mortality of 20-25%. The mortality rate in blunt chest trauma may be due to pulmonary and non-pulmonary complications. In the primary survey of chest trauma patients, 6 life-threatening conditions (airway obstruction, tension pneumothorax, open pneumothorax, massive hemothorax, flail chest, pericardial tamponade) should be immediately investigated and treated. Signs and symptoms of thoracic trauma include cyanosis of fingers, lips or face, dyspnea, tachypnea or bradypnea, contusion, laceration, perforations, distension, hemoptysis, signs of shock (hypoperfusion), tracheal deviation, paradoxical movement of the chest wall, distended jugular veins, decreased or absent breathing sounds, pain, failure of chest expansion in normal inspiration. Respiratory distress is a serious problem and the patients may breathe with nasal flaring, using accessory muscles, intercostal and subcostal retractions, and tachypnea. The patient's lungs may not be equally involved in breathing. Paradoxical respiration can be observed and immediate diagnosis of flail chest can be made.

 

Option D. Hemorrhagic shock. Shock refers to the inadequate perfusion of tissues due to the imbalance between the oxygen demand of tissues and the body’s ability to supply it. Blunt or penetrating trauma is the most common cause, followed by upper and lower gastrointestinal sources. Bleeding may be either external or internal. It occurs due to the depletion of intravascular volume through blood loss to the point of being unable to match the tissues demand for oxygen. As a result, mitochondria are unable to sustain aerobic metabolism for the production of oxygen and switch to the less efficient anaerobic metabolism to meet the cellular demand for adenosine triphosphate which leads to pyruvate production and conversion to lactic acid to maintain some degree of cellular respiration. The body compensates by increasing heart rate and contractility, followed by baroreceptor activation resulting in sympathetic nervous system activation and peripheral vasoconstriction. Signs and symptoms include blue lips and finger nails, low or no urine output, excessive sweating, shallow breathing, dizziness or loss of consciousness, confusion, chest pain, low blood pressure, rapid heart rate, weak pulse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • History of a road traffic accident, resulting in a fracture of the femur shaft with appearance of symptoms of sudden onset of difficulty breathing, confusion, and small reddish-purple skin rashes over the chest and underarm areas after a period of 12 hours all indicates fat embolism which needs immediate intervention.

choices.text: 5 alpha reductase deficiency
17 alpha hydroxylase deficiency
Androgen insensitivity syndrome

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl comes in with primary amenorrhea and indications of virilization. She displays underdeveloped breasts and pubic hair consistent with prepubertal stages, rated at Tanner stage 2. She has a closed-off vaginal canal and noticeable enlargement of the clitoris. Despite her female sex, her testosterone levels are within the male range. Her genetic makeup is 46XY. What is the likely medical diagnosis in this case? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 5 alpha reductase deficiency

 

Explanation:

 

The given scenario points to a diagnosis of 5 alpha reductase deficiency.

 

5 alpha reductase deficiency causes inability to convert testosterone to DHT.

 

When DHT levels are low, newborns will possess external genitalia with a feminine appearance. These youngsters are commonly brought up as girls until they reach puberty, at which point they begin to display signs of masculinization due to the influence of testosterone. As a result, clitoromegaly becomes evident. The absence of estrogen conversion from testosterone results in limited breast growth. Scanty pubic hair is observed since its growth is contingent on both testosterone and dihydrotestosterone.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 17 alpha hydroxylase deficiency: Leads to reduced formation of corticosteroids, sex hormones and increased mineralocorticoids (causing hypokalemia and hypertension). Patient with XY chromosome presents with atypical genitalia and undescended testes. Patient with XX chromosome lacks secondary sexual development.

 

Option C. Androgen insensitivity syndrome: Defect in androgen receptor resulting in female-appearing genetic male (46, XY); female external genitalia with scant axillary and pubic hair, rudimentary vagina; uterus and fallopian tubes absent due to persistence of anti-Mullerian hormone from testes. Patients develop normal functioning testes. Patient has increased testosterone, estrogen & LH as compared to other sex chromosome disorders.

 

Option D. Swyer syndrome: 46 XY gonadal dysgenesis; Absent secondary sexual characters, but normal female internal and external genitalia. Gonadectomy needs to be done.

 

Educational Objective:

 

5-alpha reductase deficiency causes primary amenorrhea and virilization in genetic females (46XY), resulting in the inability to convert testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT). This leads to female external genitalia at birth and masculinization at puberty, with signs such as clitoromegaly and underdeveloped breasts.

questions.text: Our physiology is designed to detect harmful substances through the perception of bitterness. Which of the substances listed below is accountable for causing this bitter taste?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alkaloids

 

Alkaloids binding to receptor à activation of GPCR à IP3/ DAG à ↑intracellular Ca2+ à  secrete ATP which in turn excites sensory afferent fibers à  bitter taste.

 

TASTE

 

 

 

 

Poison, alkaloids are bitter in taste.

 

  • Anterior 2/3rd → Chorda Tympani → 7th Nerve
  • Posterior 1/3rd → 9th Nerve
  • Posterior most (pharynx & palate) → 10th Nerve

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amino acids: Incorrect. Amino acids are not typically responsible for a bitter taste; they are usually associated with the umami taste.

 

Option C. Hydrogen ions: Incorrect. Hydrogen ions are responsible for the sour taste, not bitterness.

 

Option D. Aldehydes: Incorrect. Aldehydes are generally associated with sweet or fruity tastes, not bitterness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alkaloids are the substances responsible for causing a bitter taste, activating G-protein-coupled receptors and the IP3/DAG pathway, leading to an increase in intracellular Ca2+ and the excitation of sensory afferent fibers.

questions.text:
Identify the cause(s) that result in non-scarring alopecia from the following options: (INICET May 2023)

 

  1. Alopecia areata
  2. Telogen effluvium
  3. Androgenic alopecia
  4. Frontal fibrosing alopecia
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2 and 3

 

Non-scarring alopecia is characterized by hair loss without destruction of the hair follicle, allowing for the potential regrowth of hair. The options provided include three conditions that typically result in non-scarring alopecia:

 

1. Alopecia areata: An autoimmune disorder that causes patchy hair loss on the scalp and other parts of the body. This condition is non-scarring, as the hair follicles are not destroyed and hair can regrow if the underlying autoimmune process is controlled or subsides.

 

2. Telogen effluvium: A condition characterized by widespread thinning of the hair, often triggered by a significant stress event, illness, or hormonal change. It results from a large number of hair follicles entering the resting phase (telogen) simultaneously. Recovery is possible once the triggering event is resolved, and the follicles remain intact.

 

3. Androgenic alopecia: Commonly known as male or female pattern baldness, this is a genetic condition influenced by androgens (hormones). It involves hair thinning in a characteristic pattern and is non-scarring, as the hair follicles gradually produce thinner, shorter hairs but are not completely destroyed.

 

Other Options:

 

4. Frontal fibrosing alopecia is a form of scarring alopecia. It involves a progressive, symmetrical band of hair loss at the front of the scalp along with loss of eyebrows. The scarring means that the hair follicles are permanently destroyed, preventing the regrowth of hair.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Additional Information

questions.text: A person comes to the OPD with symptoms of not using his left side and not washing the left side of his body while bathing. On examination he wasn't able to draw the left side of the images. Which of the following is the most likely location of the lesion? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Right posterior parietal area

 

The symptoms described indicate left-sided hemi-neglect, which is typically due to a lesion in the non-dominant (right) posterior parietal area, responsible for spatial awareness and attention.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Left motor cortex: Would result in right-sided motor deficits.


Option B. Right motor cortex: Would result in left-sided motor deficits but not neglect.


Option C. Left posterior parietal area: Would result in right-sided hemi-neglect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Left-sided neglect is often due to a lesion in the right posterior parietal area.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with skin thickening muscle weakness and the peripheries becoming pale on exposure to cold. She is positive for ANA and anti-Scl-70 antibodies. Her creatinine kinase is elevated and muscle biopsy shows perifascicular infiltration. What is the antibody associated with this? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anti-PM-Scl antibody

 

The patient presents with features of scleroderma and dermatomyositis overlap syndrome. Anti-PM-Scl antibody is associated with this overlap syndrome, tends to produce nucleolar pattern in your ANA immunofluorescence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti-U3 RNP: Associated with the diffuse form of scleroderma and are also known as anti-fibrillarin antibodies.
 

Option B. Anti-centromere antibody: Associated with limited scleroderma (CREST syndrome).
 

Option D. Anti-Jo-1 antibody: Associated with antisynthetase syndrome, which predominantly causes interstitial lung disease (ILD), mechanic's hands, myositis, and Raynaud's phenomenon. It is not associated with scleroderma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-PM-Scl antibody is associated with overlap syndromes involving scleroderma and myositis.

questions.text: To which organism does the provided image of the cell wall belong? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neisseria meningitides

 

  • The displayed picture illustrates a cell wall of a gram negative bacteria
  • It shows presence of  lipooligosaccharides (LOS), which strongly indicates the presence of Neisseria meningitidis.
  • Unlike lipopolysaccharide (LPS), LOS lacks a lengthy 0-antigen side chain.
  • This unique characteristic makes it a significant virulence factor, observed in only a limited number of organisms, including N. gonorrhoeae, N. meningitidis, H. ducreyi, and others.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Staphylococcus aureus is a gram-positive bacterium and does not have a cell wall structure similar to the one depicted.

 

Option B. Escherichia coli is a gram-negative bacterium, but it has LPS instead of LOS.

 

Option D. Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative bacterium, but it has LPS rather than LOS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neisseria meningitidis is identified by the presence of lipooligosaccharides (LOS) in its cell wall, a distinguishing feature of this gram-negative bacterium.

questions.text: A 52-year-old female with diabetes mellitus has experienced a decrease in her HbA1c levels from 7.6 to 6.7 after starting a new oral medication. Laboratory tests show that she has high levels of GIP and GLP-1 and low levels of glucagon. Which of the following oral drugs was most likely administered to this patient? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Alogliptin.

 

Alogliptin is a DPP-4 inhibitor, an oral class of drugs used in the treatment of diabetes. DPP-4 inhibitors work by preventing the breakdown of GLP-1, thereby increasing the levels of GLP-1 in the body, which in turn enhances insulin secretion, reduces glucagon secretion, and slows gastric emptying.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Voglibose: Voglibose is an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor that delays the absorption of carbohydrates in the intestines. It does not directly affect the levels of incretin hormones like GLP-1 and GIP, nor does it significantly influence glucagon levels.

 

Option C. Pramlintide: Pramlintide is an amylin analogue that is used to help control blood sugar levels. It is typically administered by injection and does not significantly increase GLP-1 or GIP levels. It works by slowing gastric emptying and suppressing glucagon secretion, but it does not match the profile described in the question as closely as alogliptin.

 

Option D. Liraglutide: Liraglutide is a GLP-1 agonist, which would indeed lead to increased GLP-1 levels and decreased glucagon levels. However, liraglutide is administered by injection and not orally. This makes it less likely to be the medication described in the scenario, which specifies an oral drug.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alogliptin, a DPP-4 inhibitor, is the most likely drug responsible for the increase in GLP-1 and GIP levels and the decrease in glucagon levels in this patient. It effectively lowers HbA1c levels and is administered orally, fitting the description provided.

choices.text: Fundus and body of Gall bladder

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT an anterior relation of the third part of the duodenum? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Fundus and body of Gall bladder

 

Explanation:

 

The fundus and body of the gallbladder are not typically considered anterior relations of the third part of the duodenum. The gallbladder is situated more to the right and superior to the duodenum, so it is not directly in front of it.

 

Note - The junction of the first and second parts of the duodenum lies posterior to the neck of the gallbladder. The anterior relations of the third segment of the duodenum comprise the Superior mesenteric vessels, the Root of the mesentery, and Loops of the jejunum

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Superior mesenteric vessels: The superior mesenteric vessels, which include the superior mesenteric artery (SMA) and superior mesenteric vein (SMV), are anterior relations of the third part of the duodenum. The SMA runs just posterior to the third part of the duodenum, and the SMV is typically located to the right of the SMA and also in front of the duodenum.

 

Option B) Loops of jejunum:  Loops of the jejunum, which are part of the small intestine, can lie anterior to the third part of the duodenum. The small intestine, including the jejunum, is positioned in the abdominal cavity, and its loops can be found in close proximity to the duodenum.

 

Option C) Root of mesentery: The root of the mesentery is an extension of the peritoneum that connects the small intestine (including the jejunum and ileum) to the posterior abdominal wall. It passes in front of the third part of the duodenum as it continues to the jejunum and ileum. Therefore, it is an anterior relation of the third part of the duodenum.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: It is approved for treatment of absent seizures
Fine tremors can be noted within therapeutic range

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding lithium is correct? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Fine tremors can be noted within therapeutic range

 

Lithium is a commonly used medication for the treatment of bipolar disorder, but it can cause fine tremors within the therapeutic range. The tremors are generally mild and not a significant side effect for most patients, but in some cases, they can be bothersome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is approved for treatment of absent seizures: This is incorrect. Lithium is not used for the treatment of absent seizures. It is primarily used in the management of bipolar disorder and sometimes for treatment-resistant depression.

 

Option C. It does not cause teratogenicity: This is incorrect. Lithium can cause teratogenic effects, particularly if used during the first trimester of pregnancy. It is associated with an increased risk of cardiac anomalies, such as Ebstein's anomaly.

 

Option D. It is not absorbed orally: This is incorrect. Lithium is well absorbed orally and reaches peak plasma concentrations within a few hours of ingestion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lithium, a medication commonly used for bipolar disorder, can cause fine tremors within the therapeutic range. It is well absorbed orally and has teratogenic potential, making it important to use with caution in pregnant women.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man has arrived with a gradual swelling on the left side of his face persisting for two weeks. He had a prior incident of trauma involving wood, which occurred two months ago. A contrast-enhanced CT scan of the nasal passages and paranasal sinuses reveals a mass within the subcutaneous tissue of the left cheek. Examination of a tissue sample obtained via biopsy indicates the presence of a foreign body granuloma, with positive staining observed using PAS and GMS methods. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Phycomycosis

The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of Phycomycosis /Mucormycosis. GMS positive confirms this.

It is fungal infection which may prove rapidly fatal. It is seen in uncontrolled diabetics or in those taking immunosuppressive drugs. 

Other Options:

Option A. Midline lethal granuloma: This is a term historically used to describe aggressive midline facial granulomatous diseases, often linked to conditions like granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's granulomatosis). It does not fit the biopsy findings or clinical scenario described here.

Option B. Foreign body granuloma: Although the biopsy indicates the presence of a foreign body granuloma, the positive PAS and GMS staining suggests a fungal etiology, which is characteristic of Phycomycosis.

Option D. IgG4 granuloma: This is associated with IgG4-related disease, which presents with different clinical and histopathological findings, not typically involving PAS and GMS positive fungal elements.

Educational Objective:

Phycomycosis should be considered in patients with a history of trauma, swelling, and positive fungal stains (PAS and GMS), particularly if they have underlying conditions like diabetes or immunosuppression.

choices.text: TPE removes the von Willebrand factor
TPE removes anti-ADAMTS13 autoantibodies and thereby increases ADAMTS protease activity

questions.text: Total plasma exchange is done in thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura. How does TPE help in the management of TTP? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) TPE removes anti-ADAMTS13 autoantibodies and thereby increases ADAMTS protease activity

 

Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) is caused by a deficiency of ADAMTS13, usually due to autoantibodies. Total plasma exchange (TPE) removes these autoantibodies, thereby increasing ADAMTS13 protease activity and preventing the accumulation of large von Willebrand factor multimers. This results in platelet trapping. Classic clinical picture includes:

 

  • Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA)
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • End-organ damage (neurological injury)
  • Fever

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. TPE removes the von Willebrand factor: Incorrect; the goal is to remove autoantibodies.
 

Option B. TPE removes the antiplatelet antibodies: Incorrect; TTP involves anti-ADAMTS13 autoantibodies.
 

Option C. TPE replenishes the coagulation factors: Incorrect; TTP is not primarily a coagulation factor deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

TPE in TTP primarily removes anti-ADAMTS13 autoantibodies, increasing ADAMTS13 activity and reducing microthrombi formation.

questions.text: Identify the surgical instrument shown in the image: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mixter forceps

 

Mixter forceps is used to clamp the blood vessels and prevent blood loss and pass ligatures and dissect pedicles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adson's forceps: Adson's forceps are used in surgery to manipulate soft tissues such as fascia and skin during suturing.

 

 

Option B. Kocher's forceps: Kocher's forceps is used to clamp the blood vessels and prevent blood loss. It has 2 x 1 teeth at the tip.

 

 

Option D. Rampley forceps: Rampley forceps are used in general surgery to hold swabs and sponges or to grasp tissue. It has a fenestrated tip.

questions.text: Which of the following drug is not given in endometriosis? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Estradiol

 

Estradiol is avoided in the treatment of endometriosis because it can promote the growth of endometriotic lesions. Estradiol is a form of estrogen, which can stimulate the endometrial tissue and potentially exacerbate the symptoms and progression of endometriosis. The goal in managing endometriosis is to reduce estrogen levels or block estrogen’s effects to help resolve the lesions and alleviate symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medroxyprogesterone acetate: This is used in the treatment of endometriosis. Medroxyprogesterone acetate is a type of progesterone that helps create a state of endometrial atrophy, which can reduce the growth of endometriotic lesions.

 

Option B. Cabergoline: This drug is typically used to treat hyperprolactinemia but is not a standard treatment for endometriosis. While not commonly used in endometriosis management, its use is not contraindicated as estradiol is.

 

Option D. Letrozole: This is an aromatase inhibitor that lowers estrogen levels and is used in the treatment of endometriosis. By reducing estrogen levels, letrozole helps decrease the growth of endometriotic lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Estradiol is avoided in the treatment of endometriosis because it can exacerbate the condition by promoting the growth of endometriotic lesions

questions.text: What condition can lead to the characteristic waveform on capnography displayed by a patient under general anesthesia as observed on the ET CO2 monitor? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bronchospasm

 

Shark Fin appearance seen in bronchospasm due to anaphylaxis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Malignant hyperthermia:

 

 

Option C. Rebreathing:

 

 

Option D. Accidental extubation

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Shark Fin appearance seen in bronchospasm is due to anaphylaxis.

choices.text: Glucose tolerance test

questions.text: Which of the subsequent options is non-essential in the evaluation of mosaic Turner syndrome? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anti-nuclear antibodies

 

Out of the provided choices, the presence of anti-nuclear antibodies is not a necessary factor when investigating mosaic Turner syndrome.

 

Mosaic Turner syndrome is non-hereditary in nature. It emerges from a chance incident during the phase of cell division in the initial stages of fetal development in the impacted individual. Consequently, a portion of an individual's cells retain the standard two sex chromosomes, whereas another set of cells possess just a single X chromosome copy.

 

Features of Turner Syndrome:

 

 

Other options:

 

 

Option B. Glucose Tolerance Test: Important for detecting glucose intolerance or diabetes, which is common in Turner syndrome.

 

Option C. Audiometry: Used to assess hearing loss, which is more prevalent in individuals with Turner syndrome.

 

Option D. Echocardiography: Critical for evaluating congenital heart defects, such as coarctation of the aorta or bicuspid aortic valve, which are common in Turner syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While glucose tolerance testing, audiometry, and echocardiography are essential in the evaluation of Turner syndrome, testing for anti-nuclear antibodies is not necessary unless there is a clinical suspicion of an associated autoimmune disorder.

choices.text: Restrictive lung disease with bronchodilator reversibility
Restrictive lung disease without bronchodilator reversibility

questions.text:
A chronic cigarette smoker now joined a construction company. His pulmonary function test results are given below.(INICET MAY 2023)

 

Initial lung volumes were: FEV1 - 0.9L, FVC - 1.9L, FEV1/FVC - 0.4

 

After bronchodilation: FEV1 - 1.9L, FVC - 3.9L, FEV1/FVC - 0.4

 

What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Obstructive disease with bronchodilator reversibility

 

The pulmonary function test results show a reduced FEV1/FVC ratio, consistent with obstructive lung disease. Significant improvement in FEV1 post-bronchodilation indicates reversibility (FEV1 - anything >200ml is significant), suggesting conditions like asthma or COPD with reversible obstruction.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Vascular disease with bronchodilator reversibility: Pulmonary function tests do not suggest vascular disease.


Option B. Restrictive lung disease with bronchodilator reversibility: Restrictive diseases show reduced volumes but normal or increased FEV1/FVC ratio.


Option C. Restrictive lung disease without bronchodilator reversibility: Not applicable as the patient shows obstructive pattern with reversibility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Obstructive lung diseases, such as asthma or COPD, may show bronchodilator reversibility.

questions.text: In a patient with suspected endocrine dysfunction, which hormone primarily acts through the signaling pathway shown in the diagram below, potentially contributing to the patient's condition? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Leptin

 

The provided image depicts the JAK-STAT signaling pathway, known for its association with tyrosine kinase receptors. Within this pathway, leptin operates as one of the hormones involved. Leptin binds to its receptor, activating the JAK-STAT signaling cascade. This pathway is crucial for regulating energy balance and body weight, and its dysfunction can lead to endocrine and metabolic disorders. Leptin's role in this pathway highlights its importance in physiological processes and potential involvement in the patient's endocrine dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Calcitonin: Calcitonin primarily uses a different signaling mechanism involving G-protein-coupled receptors, not the JAK-STAT pathway.

 

Option C. Vasopressin: Vasopressin operates through G-protein-coupled receptors, particularly influencing water reabsorption in the kidneys, and does not utilize the JAK-STAT signaling pathway.

 

Option D. Aldosterone: Aldosterone acts mainly through mineralocorticoid receptors, influencing sodium and potassium balance in the kidneys, and is not involved in the JAK-STAT signaling pathway.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
Which of the following are seen in iron deficiency anemia? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Reduced serum iron level
  2. Reduced transferrin saturation
  3. Increased total iron binding capacity
  4. Reduced ferritin level
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

Iron deficiency anemia (IDA) presents with lowered serum iron levels, decreased transferrin saturation, elevated total iron-binding capacity (TIBC), and diminished ferritin levels.

 

1. Reduced Serum Iron

 

  • What it is: This is the amount of circulating iron bound to transferrin in the blood.
  • Why it decreases: In IDA, the body's iron stores are depleted due to chronic blood loss, poor dietary intake, or malabsorption, so there's less iron available to circulate.
    • Seen in IDA

 

2. Reduced Transferrin Saturation

 

  • What it is: This is the percentage of transferrin that is bound to iron.
  • Transferrin Saturation=Serum Iron​/TIBC×100
  • Why it decreases: Since serum iron is low and TIBC is high, this ratio drops.
    • Seen in IDA

 

3. Increased Total Iron-Binding Capacity (TIBC)

 

  • What it is: This reflects the maximum amount of iron that transferrin can carry.
  • Why it increases: The liver increases transferrin production in an attempt to capture more iron from the gut when body iron is low.
    • Seen in IDA

 

4. Reduced Ferritin

 

  • What it is: Ferritin is a protein that stores iron in cells and tissues.
  • Why it decreases: In IDA, body iron stores are depleted, so ferritin levels drop.
  • Important point: Ferritin is also an acute-phase reactant and may be elevated in inflammation, but in pure iron deficiency, it is low.
    • Seen in IDA

 

Summary Table

 

 

Therefore, the correct answer is:

 

C. 1, 2, 3, 4 — all of these changes are classical features of iron deficiency anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A surgeon returns the entire hernial sac into the abdominal cavity of a patient with an inguinal hernia without reducing its contents. What is this known as? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Reduction en masse

 

When the surgeon returns the entire hernial sac to the abdominal cavity without reducing its contents, this procedure is known as "reduction en masse" of the hernia.

 

Reduction en-masse of inguinal hernia means reduction/migration of a hernial sac along with the incarcerated bowel into the peritoneal cavity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Maydl's hernia: Double loop of intestine is within a hernia sac with a tight neck.

 

 

Option C. Sliding hernia: Organs like cecum (right) and sigmoid (left) accompany the sac and are present outside the sac.

 

 

Option D. Incarcerated hernia: An incarcerated hernia is a part of the intestine or abdominal tissue that becomes trapped in the sac of a hernia (irreducible).

questions.text: Liver produces KB but cannot use KB due to absence of which enzyme:  (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thiophorase

 

The liver lacks the enzyme thiophorase (succinyl-CoA:3-ketoacid CoA transferase) necessary to utilize the ketone bodies it produces. This enzyme is required to convert acetoacetate into acetoacetyl-CoA, which can then be further metabolized into two molecules of acetyl-CoA. Acetyl-CoA is a central molecule in energy metabolism and can enter the citric acid cycle (also known as the Kreb’s cycle) to produce ATP.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thiolase: It is the common enzyme of Ketone body synthesis and KB utilization.

 

Option C. HMG CoA synthase: HMG CoA synthase is RLE of ketone bodies synthesis in the liver. It is an enzyme involved in the synthesis of 3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaryl-CoA (HMG-CoA), a precursor molecule in the production of cholesterol and ketone bodies. However, the absence of HMG CoA synthase would impact the overall synthesis of ketone bodies rather than their utilization.

 

Option D. HMG CoA reductase: HMG CoA reductase is an enzyme involved in the synthesis of mevalonate, which is a precursor molecule in the production of cholesterol. However, the absence of HMG CoA reductase in the liver would not directly affect the utilization of ketone bodies. It would primarily impact the synthesis of cholesterol and other downstream products.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The liver plays a crucial role in ketone body metabolism. During periods of prolonged fasting or low carbohydrate intake, the liver produces ketone bodies (acetoacetate and β-hydroxybutyrate) through a process called ketogenesis. These ketone bodies are then released into the bloodstream and can be used as an alternative fuel source by various tissues, including the brain, heart, and skeletal muscles.

questions.text: A person who has undergone a bone marrow transplant in the past is now presenting with a lung lesion. Upon microscopic analysis, the image of the lesion is provided below. What is the probable responsible organism for this condition? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Mucormycosis

 

Explanation:

 

Mucormycosis is indicated in this clinical scenario due to the patient's history of a bone marrow transplant and the presence of a lung lesion. The image provided shows broad aseptate hyphae , which is characteristic of Mucormycosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Histoplasma: Is a dimorphic fungus. At 25°C, it shows mycelial phase and at 37°C, it shows Yeast form.

 

 

Option B. Cryptococcus: Colonies can be demonstrated by negative staining of their capsule.

 

 

Option D. Aspergillosis: Shows narrow, acute angled branching and septate, differing from the non-septate hyphae

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mucormycosis  is characterized broad aseptate hyphae with acute -angle branching. which commonly affecting in immunocompromised patients.

questions.text: What is the most frequent cause of adrenal incidentaloma? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Non-functioning adenoma

 

Most frequent cause of adrenal incidentaloma is Non-functioning adenoma

 

An adrenal incidentaloma is an unexpected adrenal mass detected on imaging not performed for suspected adrenal disease.

 

Non-functioning adrenal adenomas do not secrete hormones in significant amounts to cause clinical syndromes. They are benign tumors that are often discovered incidentally on imaging studies. Histologically, they are similar to hormone-secreting adenomas, but they do not produce clinical symptoms or biochemical abnormalities. They are the most common type of adrenal incidentaloma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subclinical Cushing's syndrome: Subclinical Cushing's syndrome refers to the mild or asymptomatic cortisol excess from an adrenal adenoma. These patients lack the full-blown signs and symptoms of overt Cushing's syndrome but might show subtle manifestations of cortisol excess or have abnormal laboratory findings.

 

Option B. Aldosterone producing adenoma: Aldosterone producing adenomas are a cause of primary hyperaldosteronism. They produce excess aldosterone leading to hypertension and hypokalemia. Patients may have suppressed renin levels in the blood due to feedback inhibition from the elevated aldosterone.

 

Option C. Pheochromocytoma: Pheochromocytomas are tumors of the adrenal medulla that produce excessive amounts of catecholamines (e.g., epinephrine and norepinephrine). Symptoms often include paroxysms of hypertension, headache, sweating, and palpitations. While these are serious tumors, they are a less common cause of adrenal incidentalomas.

questions.text: A male patient is being treated for a mood disorder. After starting a new medication, he experiences priapism, a prolonged, painful erection. The healthcare provider is considering changing the medication. Which drug is most likely responsible for causing priapism in this patient? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Trazodone

 

Trazodone is an atypical antidepressant that is often used off-label for insomnia. It is known to cause priapism as a rare but serious side effect. Given that the patient has a mood disorder and experienced priapism, trazodone is the most likely culprit.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Venlafaxine: This is a serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI) used to treat depression and anxiety disorders. While sexual dysfunction is a potential side effect, it is not commonly associated with priapism.

 

Option C. Bupropion: This is an atypical antidepressant used for depression and smoking cessation. It is not commonly associated with priapism as a side effect.

 

Option D. Mirtazapine: This is another atypical antidepressant used for depression. It also has a low likelihood of causing priapism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trazodone is the most likely antidepressant to cause priapism among the listed options due to its known side effect profile. This serious condition necessitates careful monitoring and potentially switching medications to prevent recurrence.

questions.text: What is an infrequent yet highly serious adverse outcome of clozapine that necessitates consistent monitoring?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Agranulocytosis

 

CLOZAPINE

 

  • Treatment-resistant schizophrenia (TRS)- Lack of response to at least two different antipsychotics, including at least one second-generation antipsychotic, given in adequate dosage and for an adequate duration (at least 4-6 weeks).
  • Clozapine is the drug of choice (DOC) in TRS.
  • Unique mechanism of action- More affinity for D4 than D2, hence causes minimal EPS.
  • Antipsychotic that causes max weight gain.
  • Clozapine is the only antipsychotic with antisuicide property.

 

Side effects of clozapine

 

  • Life-threatening: Agranulocytosis (idiosyncratic), myocarditis (idiosyncratic), seizures (dose-dependent)
  • Sedation (most common), sialorrhea
  • Syncope, hypotension, tachycardia, nausea, vomiting
  • Weight gain, anticholinergic side effects
  • Due to the possibility of agranulocytosis, when a patient is on clozapine, ANC and TLC monitoring is required.
  • The regime of monitoring-
    • First 6 months- Once a week
    • Next 6 months- Once in two weeks
    • After 1 year- Once in four weeks, till clozapine is continued 
  • Stop clozapine, if WBC < 3000/dl or ANC < 1500/dl
  • Contraindications for clozapine use
    • WBC < 3500/dl
    • History of agranulocytosis on clozapine
    • Use of other bone marrow suppressants like carbamazepine

questions.text: What is the optimal urine output for a patient who has undergone laparoscopic cholecystectomy? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 0.5-1.5 ml/kg/hour

 

After a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, it is anticipated that the patient will have a normal urine output during the postoperative phase, which is 0.5-1.5 ml/kg/hour.

 

If converted into ml/day, approximately 1500 ml/day in an avg. adult

 

If converted into ml/minute, approximately 1 to 1.5 ml/minute in an avg. adult

 

If converted into ml/kg, approximately 12-36 ml/day in an avg. adult

questions.text: Match the characteristics resulting from the compression of the listed structures in the event of thyroid enlargement. (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 1-c, 2-d, 3-b, 4-a

 

Explanation

 

  1. Trachea - c. Dyspnea (Difficulty Breathing): Thyroid enlargement can lead to the compression of the trachea (windpipe), causing narrowing of the airway. This compression can result in difficulty breathing, also known as dyspnea.
  2. Esophagus - d. Dysphagia (Difficulty Swallowing): When the thyroid gland enlarges and presses against the esophagus (the tube that carries food from the mouth to the stomach), it can interfere with the normal swallowing process, leading to dysphagia or difficulty swallowing.
  3. Sympathetic Chain - b. Horner's Syndrome: Compression of the sympathetic chain, which runs along the sides of the neck, can result in Horner's syndrome. Horner's syndrome includes signs such as ptosis (drooping of the upper eyelid), miosis (constricted pupil), and anhidrosis (lack of sweating) on one side of the face. Thyroid enlargement can affect sympathetic nerve fibers and lead to these symptoms.
  4. Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve - a. Hoarseness: The recurrent laryngeal nerve innervates the muscles responsible for vocal cord movement. Compression or damage to this nerve due to thyroid enlargement can result in hoarseness of voice and voice changes.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Match the following drugs with the receptors they act upon: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. A-3, B-4, C-1, D-2

 

 

Other Options:

 

A-3. Mirabegron acts on β3 receptors. Mirabegron is a β3 adrenergic receptor agonist used for the treatment of bladder incontinence by relaxing the detrusor muscle during the storage phase of the urinary bladder fill-void cycle.

 

B-4. Indacaterol acts on β2 receptors. Indacaterol is a long-acting β2 adrenergic agonist used in the treatment of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

 

C-1. Betaxolol acts on β1 receptors. Betaxolol is a β1 selective blocker used in the treatment of hypertension and glaucoma.

 

D-2. Isoproterenol acts on β1 β2 receptors. Isoproterenol is a non-selective β adrenergic agonist with no α action, used in the treatment of bradycardia and heart block.

questions.text:
What diseases' risk is elevated due to smoking? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Duct ectasia
  2. Fibroadenoma
  3. Mondor's disease
  4. Breast carcinoma
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 3, 4

 

Cigarette smoking elevates the likelihood of experiencing duct ectasia, Mondor's disease, and breast carcinoma.

 

1. Duct ectasia: Typically seen in smokers. Patient presents with greenish Nipple discharge and Lump in breast with nipple retraction. Management is done by Conical excision of ductal system - Hadfield procedure.

 

3. Mondor's disease: Superficial thrombophlebitis of veins of breast / chest wall or axilla – males. Patient presents with cord like, thick, tender initially. Most common vein involves lateral thoracic vein. Smoking was identified as a possible contributing element in the development of Mondor's disease.

 

4. Breast carcinoma: Risk factors involve Age > 60, Early menarche (< 12 years), late menopause (>55 years), nulli-parity, late age of first child birth, Hormone replacement therapy, Inadequate breast feeding (breast feeding for > 12 months reduces risk), Alcohol & smoking consumption, obesity, Prior chest wall radiation, Family history.

 

Other Option:

 

2. Fibroadenoma: Tumor of breast arising from ductal epithelium or fibrous elements or both. It has two components – fibrous or stromal elements + glandular elements. Patient presents with slow growing lump (2-3cm), mobile like a mouse in breast. Smoking is not a risk factor for fibroadenomas.

choices.text: Decreases risk of Colon cancer
Decreased risk of breast cancer
Decreased risk of endometrial cancer
Increases risk of osteoporosis

questions.text: Which of the following is a true association related to HRT (Hormone replacement therapy) among the options provided? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Decreases risk of Colon cancer

 

Explanation:

 

Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT) has been associated with a decreased risk of colon cancer. Studies have shown that estrogen in HRT may have a protective effect against the development of colon cancer. This effect is believed to be related to estrogen’s impact on gastrointestinal mucosal growth and repair.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Decreased risk of breast cancer: This option is incorrect. HRT, particularly with estrogen and progestin, is associated with an increased risk of breast cancer. Long-term use of combined HRT has been shown to elevate the risk of breast cancer in several studies.

 

Option C. Decreased risk of endometrial cancer: This option is incorrect. Unopposed estrogen (estrogen alone without progestin) increases the risk of endometrial cancer. To mitigate this risk, progestin is often added to HRT in women with an intact uterus.

 

Option D. Increases risk of osteoporosis: This option is incorrect. HRT is actually used prophylactically to reduce the risk of osteoporosis. Estrogen helps maintain bone density and prevent bone loss, which is beneficial in managing osteoporosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT) decreases the risk of colon cancer.

choices.text: Carotid body chemoreceptors
Autonomic brain stem regulation

questions.text: In a fetal monitoring, which of the following factors primarily contributes to an increase in fetal heart rate acceleration during labor and delivery, signifying fetal well-being? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Carotid body chemoreceptors

 

The carotid body chemoreceptors play a crucial role in monitoring and responding to changes in blood oxygen levels, particularly during labor and delivery. These receptors are highly sensitive to decreases in blood oxygen levels (hypoxia) and increases in carbon dioxide levels (hypercapnia). When activated, they send signals to the brainstem to increase respiratory rate and heart rate, thereby ensuring adequate oxygen supply to the fetus.

 

During labor, the fetus can experience transient periods of hypoxia due to contractions and reduced placental blood flow. The carotid body chemoreceptors detect these changes and contribute to fetal heart rate acceleration, which is an important indicator of fetal well-being.

 

 

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Aortic baroreceptors: Incorrect. Aortic baroreceptors are primarily involved in regulating blood pressure by detecting changes in arterial pressure and do not directly contribute to fetal heart rate acceleration in response to hypoxia.

 

Option C. Autonomic brain stem regulation: Incorrect. While the autonomic brainstem plays a role in overall cardiovascular regulation, the direct response to hypoxia and resulting heart rate acceleration is mediated by chemoreceptors.

 

Option D. ANP (Atrial Natriuretic Peptide): Incorrect. ANP is involved in regulating blood volume and pressure by promoting sodium and water excretion, but it does not directly influence fetal heart rate acceleration during labor.

 

Educational Objective

 

Carotid body chemoreceptors are primarily responsible for detecting changes in blood oxygen levels and contributing to fetal heart rate acceleration during labor, indicating fetal well-being.

choices.text: Matzke scale
Salazar scale
Rummack-mathew scale

questions.text: Vancomycin nomogram is known as (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Matzke scale

 

The Vancomycin nomogram is also known as the Matzke nomogram or the Matzke scale. It is a tool used to help predict the appropriate dose of vancomycin, an antibiotic, based on the patient's creatinine clearance and trough serum concentration. The nomogram is a graphical representation that allows healthcare providers to quickly and easily determine the optimal dose of vancomycin for a given patient, taking into account factors such as kidney function and the patient's weight.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Salazar scale: This nomogram is not related to vancomycin dosing. It is used to predict overall survival of patients with cancer.

 

Option C. Rummack-Matthew scale: This is used to assess potential hepatotoxicity after acetaminophen intake based on serum acetaminophen concentration.

 

Option D. Krutzko scale: There is no widely recognized medical scale or nomogram known as the Krutzko scale.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Vancomycin nomogram, also known as the Matzke scale, is a crucial tool for determining the appropriate dosing of vancomycin based on creatinine clearance and trough serum concentration, ensuring both efficacy and safety in patient treatment.

questions.text: Identify the type of hypoxia according to given graph: (Brown graph is normal) (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Anemic hypoxia

 

The given graph illustrates a 50% reduction in the oxygen saturation of hemoglobin, even though the partial pressure of oxygen (PO2) stays within the expected range. This state is termed anemic hypoxia.

 

Anemic hypoxia occurs when there is a reduction in the oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood, usually due to a lower amount of hemoglobin, as seen in anemia. Despite normal levels of PO2, the overall oxygen content in the blood is diminished, leading to insufficient oxygen delivery to tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stagnant hypoxia: This occurs when oxygen deficiency is due to poor blood circulation, not a reduced oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood. It is caused by issues like arterial obstruction or ischemia. The graph for stagnant hypoxia would show normal oxygen content in arterial blood but lower content in venous blood due to poor perfusion.

 

Option B. Histotoxic hypoxia: In this type, the cells are unable to utilize oxygen effectively, even though it is adequately supplied by the blood. This condition is typically caused by toxins like cyanide that impair cellular respiration. The graph for histotoxic hypoxia would show normal oxygen content in both arterial and venous blood since the issue is within the cells' ability to use oxygen, not the blood's ability to transport it.

 

Option C. Hypoxic hypoxia: This occurs when there is a generalized lack of oxygen in the body's tissues due to low oxygen in the blood, often seen at high altitudes or in conditions like COPD. The graph would show reduced PO2 along with decreased oxygen content in both arterial and venous blood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  1. Stagnant hypoxia: Oxygen deficiency due to poor blood circulation.
  2. Histotoxic hypoxia: Cells unable to utilize oxygen despite its availability.
  3. Hypoxic hypoxia: Generalized lack of oxygen in the body's tissues.
  4. Anemic hypoxia: Reduced oxygen-carrying capacity of blood due to low hemoglobin.

choices.text: Rest pain is seen more in the night
Pain in intermittent claudication comes at first step of walking.
The clinical stem does not reflect the site of peripheral arterial obstruction

questions.text: Which of the statements regarding claudication pain is incorrect? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pain in intermittent claudication comes at first step of walking.

 

Intermittent claudication is characterized by muscle pain (ache, cramp, numbness or sense of fatigue), classically in the calf muscle, which occurs during exercise and is relieved by a short period of rest (< 5 minutes). The pain does not typically start with the first step but develops after a predictable distance of walking.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rest pain is seen more in the night: True. Rest pain is a more severe symptom of peripheral artery disease (PAD). It typically indicates more advanced disease than intermittent claudication. This pain occurs when the limb is at rest, often at night due to the decreased perfusion that results from the horizontal position of the limb. It often awakens the patient from sleep and can be relieved by hanging the leg over the bed or walking.

 

Option C. Most common cause is atheroma: True. The most common cause of intermittent claudication is atherosclerosis (plaque or atheroma formation) in the peripheral arteries. This reduces blood flow to the muscles during activity, causing pain.

 

Option D. The clinical stem does not reflect the site of peripheral arterial obstruction: True. The site of pain (e.g., calf, thigh) does not always directly correlate with the level of arterial obstruction. For instance, while calf pain is often due to femoropopliteal disease, it can also be caused by aortoiliac disease. However, the location of claudication pain can provide a clue to the level of disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The incorrect statement among the provided options is that pain in intermittent claudication occurs at the first step of walking.

questions.text: Match the diseases with their maximum incubation period. (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-d, 2-c, 3-a, 4-b

 

The incubation periods for the diseases listed are as follows:

 

  • Hepatitis A: Maximum incubation period is 50 days.
  • Chickenpox: Maximum incubation period is 21 days.
  • SARS: Maximum incubation period is 10 days.

choices.text: CCK - I cells, Duodenum and jejunum
Motilin - M cells, Duodenum and Jejunum

questions.text: Which of the subsequent pairs are inaccurately matched? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Motilin - M cells, Duodenum and Jejunum

 

Motilin is a gastrointestinal hormone produced by enterochromaffin cells and Mo cells present in the stomach, small intestine, and colon.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastrin - G cells, Antrum: Correct. Gastrin is produced by G cells located in the antrum of the stomach and stimulates H+ secretion by parietal cells.

 

Option B. Secretin - S cells, Duodenum: Correct. Secretin is produced by S cells in the duodenum and decreases gastric acid secretion while increasing pancreatic bicarbonate secretion.

 

Option C. CCK - I cells, Duodenum and jejunum: Correct. Cholecystokinin (CCK) is produced by I cells in the duodenum and jejunum, increasing pancreatic enzyme secretion and gallbladder contraction while decreasing gastric emptying and relaxing the sphincter of Oddi.

 

Option D. Motilin - M cells, Duodenum and Jejunum: Incorrect. Motilin is produced by enterochromaffin cells and Mo cells in the stomach, small intestine, and colon, not exclusively by M cells in the duodenum and jejunum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

GIT HORMONES

 

  • Gastrin – G cell at antrum. Acts on Parietal cells stimulate the H+ K+ ATPase.
  • Secretin – S cells at Duodenum. Decrease gastric acid secretion and Increase pancreatic HCO3- secretion.
  • CCK-PZ – I cells in duodenum and jejunum. Increase pancreatic HCO3- secretion, Increase gall bladder contraction, Decrease gastric emptying and increase sphincter of Oddi relaxation.
  • GIP – K cells in duodenum and jejunum. Decrease H+ secretion and increase insulin release.
  • Motilin – Mo cells in small intestine. Produces migrating motor complexes (MMCs).

questions.text: What is the purpose of using the SCOFF protocol? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Eating disorder

 

The SCOFF questionnaire seems highly effective as a screening instrument for detecting eating disorders.

 

SCOFF QUESTIONS

 

  1. Do you make yourself Sick because you feel uncomfortably full?
  2. Do you worry you have lost Control over how much you eat?
  3. Have you recently lost more than One stone in a 3-month period?
  4. Do you believe yourself to be Fat when others say you are too thin?
  5. Would you say that Food dominates your life?

 

*One point for every “yes”; a score of ⩾2 indicates a likely case of anorexia nervosa or bulimia

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with weight loss and fever. The patient reports a history of blood in the stool and vomiting two weeks ago. Upon examination, tenderness is noted in the right hypochondrium along with an enlarged liver (hepatomegaly). An abdominal CT scan reveals a lesion in the right liver lobe characterized by irregular borders, several partitions, and varied densities. What is the most probable diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Amoebic liver abscess

 

The most probable diagnosis in this case is C) Amoebic liver abscess.

 

1. Clinical Presentation:

 

  • The patient presents with weight loss and fever, which are common symptoms associated with liver abscesses.
  • A history of blood in the stool and vomiting two weeks ago may suggest an underlying gastrointestinal infection, likely to be amebic colitis.

 

2. Physical Examination Findings:

 

  • Tenderness in the right hypochondrium (upper right abdomen) suggests liver involvement.
  • Enlarged liver (hepatomegaly) is a common finding in liver abscesses.

 

3. Imaging Findings:

 

  • The description of the lesion on the abdominal CT scan is characteristic of an amoebic liver abscess. These abscesses typically have irregular borders, several partitions (internal septations), and varied densities due to necrotic tissue and pus formation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pyogenic liver abscess: Can also cause similar symptoms and imaging findings but will often present with high grade fever and chills, and is usually multiple.

 

Option B. Hydatid cyst: Typically presents as a well-defined cystic lesion on imaging and is caused by the Echinococcus parasite. It will not be preceded by a colitis type of event. It's less likely given the description of irregular borders and partitions in the lesion.

 

Option D. Hemangiomas: Hemangiomas are usually benign vascular tumors and are unlikely to cause the presented symptoms or imaging findings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The combination of clinical symptoms, physical examination findings, and the characteristic imaging features of an irregular, partitioned lesion in the liver makes amoebic liver abscess the most probable diagnosis in this case

 

 

ANCHOVY SAUCE – STERILE PUS SEEN IN AMEBIC LIVER ABSCESS

choices.text: White leathery foam around mouth and nostrils

questions.text: An autopsy was performed on a woman who was reportedly discovered near a village lake. Among the listed factors, which one does not indicate drowning prior to death:(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Washerwoman's hands and feet

 

Washerwoman's hands and feet just indicates that body was immersed in water. It does not specify whether the person died due to drowning or not. It occurs due to infiltration of water into the outer layers of the skin, which will occur irrespective whether the person died due to drowning or the body was thrown in water after death.

 

 

If a body is recovered from water, the there are two different kind of signs to look for:

 

  1. Signs of Antemortem Drowning: These will indicate that person died due to drowning.
  2. Signs of Immersion: These will only indicate that the body was in water.

 

Signs of Antemortem Drowning (in descending order of accuracy):

 

  • Grass or weeds tightly held in hands (cadaveric Spasm): Surest sign
  • Drowning Froth Over Mouth and Nose and in air passages: Second best sign
  • Emphysema Aquosum (overinflated lungs)
  • Presence of sand / mud etc. in respiratory passages especially in terminal part
  • Diatom test
  • Presence of water especially if mixed with mud / sand etc. in Stomach or intestines
  • Paltauff Haemorrhage (Subpleural Haemorrhage)
  • Gettler’s test

 

Signs of Immersion

 

  • Washerwoman’s hand / feet
  • Cutis anserina=goose skin

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Water in stomach: This suggests that the person was alive when entering the water and swallowed water, indicating antemortem drowning.

 

Option C. White leathery foam around mouth and nostrils: This foam, often referred to as "drowning froth," is a strong indicator of antemortem drowning as it forms when water mixes with air and mucus in the airways.

 

Option D. Positive diatom test: The presence of diatoms in the organs indicates that the person inhaled water while still alive, allowing these microscopic algae to enter the bloodstream and be deposited in various tissues, thus confirming antemortem drowning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Washerwoman's hands and feet indicate immersion in water but do not specify drowning as the cause of death, unlike other indicators such as water in the stomach, white leathery foam, and a positive diatom test, which strongly suggest antemortem drowning.

questions.text:
Under which circumstances is live vaccination not contraindicated? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. DiGeorge syndrome
  2. Wiskott Aldrich Syndrome
  3. Ataxia telangiectasia
  4. Complement deficiency
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 4 only

 

Live vaccinations are generally contraindicated in individuals with certain immunodeficiency disorders because their immune systems may not be able to handle the attenuated (weakened) pathogens in the vaccines, potentially leading to severe infections. However, there are exceptions based on the nature of the immunodeficiency.

 

  • Complement deficiency: This is a condition where components of the complement system (a part of the immune system) are deficient. Complement deficiencies do not affect the cellular immune response significantly, meaning that the risk of adverse effects from live vaccinations is not increased. Therefore, individuals with complement deficiency can receive live vaccines safely.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. DiGeorge syndrome: DiGeorge syndrome involves a defect in T-cell production due to thymic hypoplasia. Since T-cells are crucial for mounting an immune response to vaccines, live vaccines are contraindicated.

 

Option C. Ataxia telangiectasia: This is a condition characterized by defects in both the immune system and DNA repair mechanisms. Patients with this condition have a higher risk of developing severe infections from live vaccines, so they are contraindicated.

 

Option D. Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome: This is an X-linked recessive disorder affecting both the immune system and platelet production. Individuals with Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome are at risk for severe infections from live vaccines due to their compromised immune function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Complement deficiency does not pose a contraindication for live vaccination.

 

However, it is important to note that live vaccines should be avoided in individuals with DiGeorge syndrome, Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome, and Ataxia telangiectasia, because these are immunodeficiency disorders.

questions.text: A young man, aged 25, arrived with complaints of being unable to bend the distal interphalangeal joint of his 4th and 5th fingers. Additionally, he faced difficulty in gripping a piece of paper between his fingers. Where is the probable location of the injury? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. C

 

  • The given clinical scenario depicts paralysis of medial 2 lumbricals and palmar interossei which are supplied by ulnar nerve.
  • Ulnar nerve lies behind medial epicondyle, marked as C in the given image.
  • Ulnar nerve supplies Flexor carpi ulnaris & medial half of flexor digitorum profundus in forearm and in hand, it gives motor supply to hypothenar muscles, adductor pollicis, all interossei and medial two lumbricals.

 

ULNAR NERVE PALSY

 

  1. High ulnar nerve palsy (Injury proximal to elbow): Paralysis of all muscles supplied ulnar nerve in forearm and hand. Sensory deficit in the skin of hand.
  2. Low ulnar nerve palsy (Injury distal one third of forearm): Sparing of forearm muscles, Paralysis of hand muscles. Sensory deficit in the skin of hand.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The structure marked as A is the deltoid tuberosity. Injury to this part is rare. Its superficial location places it at a risk of trauma, fracture, and sequestration.

 

Option B. The structure marked as B is the lateral epicondyle. The lateral epicondyle is usually involved in the lateral epicondylitis or tennis elbow i.e., the overuse injury secondary to the eccentric overload of the common extensor tendon at the origin of extensor carpi radialis brevis (ECRB) tendon.

 

Option D. The structure marked as D is the anatomical neck of humerus. Here, the shoulder joint capsule is attached. Injury to this part is highly uncommon.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The marked structure C is the medial epicondyle. The Ulnar nerve passes from behind the epicondyle. Injury to the ulnar nerve at this area causes ulnar claw hand i.e., the extension of IP joints of 4th and 5th fingers; along with weakness in grip of the hand.

questions.text: A 14-year-old patient arrives at the OPD with a concern about her ability to perceive speech sounds while struggling to comprehend the actual words being spoken. Her Pure Tone Audiometry (PTA) and Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA) results show discrepancies, as the PTA is relatively within the normal range. However, her mid-latency and cortical responses are both non-existent. What probable diagnosis can be inferred from these findings? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Auditory neuropathy

 

If a child arrives with concerns about not being able to comprehend words, and their BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry) results are abnormal while their PTA (Pure Tone Audiometry) results are normal, this could indicate the presence of auditory neuropathy.

 

Auditory neuropathy is a neurologic disorder of CN VIII. Audiometric tests, e.g. SNHL for pure tones, impaired speech discrimination score, absent or abnormal auditory brainstem response, show a retrocochlear type of lesion but OAEs are normal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Michel aplasia also known as complete labyrinthine aplasia, is the most severe congenital inner ear malformation, characterized by complete absence of inner ear structures. This condition would present with profound hearing loss detected on PTA, not normal PTA results.

 

Option C. Malingering: Intentional falsification of hearing loss would likely be exposed by objective tests like BERA, which would not show the abnormal results observed in this case.

 

Option D. Cochlear otosclerosis shows Carhart’s notch (dip at 2000 Hz in bone conduction) on PTA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Auditory neuropathy should be suspected in patients who present with normal hearing sensitivity on pure tone audiometry but show significant difficulties with speech comprehension and abnormal brainstem evoked response audiometry results.

questions.text: A person arrived with a lesion on their left buttock. This individual has a past medical record of undergoing a heart transplant 15 years ago. Analysis of the fluid extracted from the lesion reveals the presence of gram-positive filamentous bacteria. What is the probable microbial agent responsible for this condition? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nocardia

 

The provided clinical situation involving a localized abscess and an aspirate displaying filamentous gram-positive bacteria indicates a likelihood of Nocardia infection.

 

  • Nocardia is a gram-positive branching filamentous bacilli.

 

 

  • Modified acid-fast staining: using 1% sulfuric acid as decolorizer (Kinyoun method): Nocardiae are partially acid-fast and appear as branching and filamentous red colored acid-fast bacilli.

 

 

  • Histopathology (H and E stain) of the granules: Shows multilobulated with sun-ray appearance.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Bacillus anthracis, on culture, are arranged end-to-end in long chains → Bamboo-stick appearance.

 

 

Option C. Mycobacterium leprae is an acid-fast, Gram-positive, rod shaped bacterium and an obligate intracellular parasite.

 

 

Option D. Mycobacterium tuberculosis appear weakly Gram-positive. Acid fast stain is used to identify it.

 

 

 

Educational Objective

 

Nocardia is a gram-positive, branching filamentous bacillus, particularly seen in immunocompromised patients, and can be identified using modified acid-fast staining.

choices.text: Usually symptomatic with dyspnoea, dysphagia and SVC syndrome
Chest Xray is the investigation of choice

questions.text: What is the accurate statement regarding thymoma? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Most common neoplasm of thymus

 

Thymomas are indeed the most common primary tumors of the thymus. These tumors originate from the epithelial cells of the thymus, an organ located in the anterior mediastinum. While they can be associated with various systemic syndromes, particularly myasthenia gravis, they may also be asymptomatic and are sometimes discovered incidentally.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Most common posterior mediastinal tumor: This statement is incorrect. Thymomas are tumors of the anterior mediastinum, not the posterior. Neurogenic tumors are the most common tumors in the posterior mediastinum.

 

Option C. Usually symptomatic with dyspnoea, dysphagia and SVC syndrome: Thymomas can be asymptomatic or they may present with symptoms due to compression of nearby structures. While they can cause symptoms like dyspnea (shortness of breath) if they compress the trachea or lungs, or symptoms of Superior Vena Cava (SVC) syndrome if they compress the SVC, these are not the most common presentations. The association with systemic syndromes like myasthenia gravis is more characteristic.

 

Option D. Chest Xray is the investigation of choice: While a chest X-ray can identify a mediastinal mass suggesting a thymoma, a computed tomography (CT) scan of the chest is usually the investigation of choice for further characterization and to evaluate the exact size, location, and any local invasion. The CT scan provides more detailed images than a simple chest X-ray.

questions.text:
What is/are correct statement(s) regarding skeletal muscle? (INICET May 2023)

 

  1. Extracellular calcium entry is important in the skeletal muscle contraction.
  2. Calcium is mainly released from mitochondria.
  3. Calcium is released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum.
  4. Voltage-gated calcium channel on sarcolemma has no role in excitation-contraction coupling.
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Only 3

 

The accurate fact concerning skeletal muscle is that the release of calcium occurs from the sarcoplasmic reticulum.

 

Other Options:

 

1. Extracellular calcium plays a significant role in sustaining cardiac muscle contraction.

 

2. The sarcoplasmic reticulum is filled with high concentrations of calcium ions stored in its vesicular tubules. Upon the occurrence of an action potential in the neighboring T tubule, these calcium ions are discharged from each vesicle.

 

4. Activation of receptor results in the initiation of calcium release channels, leading to the liberation of calcium ions into the sarcoplasm surrounding the myofibrils, consequently triggering muscle contraction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum is essential for skeletal muscle contraction.

questions.text: The vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR) functions to stabilize the image on the retina during head movement. What is the ratio of eye velocity to head velocity, known as the VOR gain?  (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1

 

The vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR) gain is 1, indicating that the eyes move at a compensatory velocity equal to the velocity of the head, but in the opposite direction.

 

The vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR) allows for eye movements in the opposite direction of head movement to maintain steady gaze and prevent retinal image slip. Nerves involved are 3, 6 & 8.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct VOR gain is crucial for visual stability.
